categories.name: Popular culture, entertainment and the arts

subCategories.name: Popular culture, entertainment and the arts - General

articles.title: Folly
articles.teaserText: Buildings prized for their uselessness.

articles.title: Gravity hill
articles.teaserText: A hill that gives the illusion of objects rolling up it.

articles.title: Pizza farm
articles.teaserText: All the ingredients of pizza, grown in one convenient location!

articles.title: Rocket garden
articles.teaserText: Landscaping and rocketry, together at last.

articles.title: Spite house
articles.teaserText: Various houses built solely out of spite for their neighbors.

articles.title: Valeriepieris circle
articles.teaserText: You either live inside the circle or outside. Even though you live inside.

articles.title: Bir Tawil
articles.teaserText: One of the few places on Earth not claimed by any country. An American trekked there and claimed it in 2014 as the Kingdom of North Sudan so he could make his daughter a princess.

articles.title: Congo Pedicle
articles.teaserText: What happens when a tyrannical king decides he wants to hunt game in a swamp.

articles.title: Gaet'ale Pond
articles.teaserText: A small lake in Ethiopia that was created in 2005 after an earthquake. It's not bitter, it's just really, really salty.

articles.title: Jacob's Ladder (Saint Helena)
articles.teaserText: It's all very downhill from here.

articles.title: Lake Nyos
articles.teaserText: A lake in northwestern Cameroon that exploded in 1986, killing 1,746 people. One of 3 known exploding lakes, the others being Lake Monoun and Lake Kivu.

articles.title: Oklo Mine
articles.teaserText: The former site of the world's only natural nuclear fission reactors.

articles.title: Peñón de Vélez de la Gomera
articles.teaserText: A rock on the Moroccan coast connected to the mainland by an 80-metre-wide (260 ft) tombolo; it is owned by Spain.

articles.title: Republic of Benin (1967)
articles.teaserText: One of the shortest-lived states in history, it was independent for only seven hours (07:00 to 14:00 on 19 September 1967).

articles.title: Blood Falls
articles.teaserText: A naturally occurring plume of saltwater that is blood red thanks to its high iron oxide content.

articles.title: Mawson Peak
articles.teaserText: The tallest mountain in Australia is not on the mainland, but on a barren, uninhabited island more than 3,800 kilometres (2,400 mi) away.

articles.title: McMurdo Dry Valleys
articles.teaserText: An area of Antarctica that a) contains an extremely saline body of water and b) has not experienced rainfall for over two million years.

articles.title: Marie Byrd Land
articles.teaserText: The largest unclaimed territory in the world. Notable for being bigger than Mongolia, having one of Antarctica's biggest human bases, and being the setting of The Thing.

articles.title: Artsvashen
articles.teaserText: An Armenian town surrounded and controlled by Azerbaijan. One of a number of similar towns on this border; others include Yukhari Askipara, Barxudarlı and Karki.

articles.title: Atar, Padang Ganting
articles.teaserText: An Indonesian village with a monument resembling a photocopier.

articles.title: Camp Bonifas
articles.teaserText: The bunkers on this golf course feature machine-guns and landmines.

articles.title: Dahala Khagrabari
articles.teaserText: India inside Bangladesh inside India inside Bangladesh. Formerly the only third-order enclave in the world.

articles.title: Darvaza gas crater
articles.teaserText: A flaming, 70 m (230 ft) wide, 30 m (98 ft) deep crater in the middle of the Karakum Desert, on fire since 1971.

articles.title: Dhekelia Power Station
articles.teaserText: A Cypriot power station that provides power to a British military base that surrounds it.

articles.title: Diomede Islands
articles.teaserText: Two islands in the Bering Strait separated by 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) and 21 hours' time difference.

articles.title: Gangkhar Puensum
articles.teaserText: The tallest mountain nobody has ever summitted, as the Bhutanese government has prohibited mountaineering since 2003.

articles.title: Gate Tower Building
articles.teaserText: A skyscraper in Japan that has a highway offramp passing through its fifth, sixth and seventh floors.

articles.title: Hallstatt (China)
articles.teaserText: An ongoing replica construction of a town in Austria.

articles.title: Hanazono Room
articles.teaserText: An indoor swimming pool in Japan used as the site for many pornographic films.

articles.title: Jewish Autonomous Oblast
articles.teaserText: In the depth of Eastern Siberia there's a place with street names in Yiddish, even though 99% of its population is not Jewish.

articles.title: Kai Tak Airport
articles.teaserText: A major international airport closed in 1998 where planes literally almost crashed constantly into the city due to a right-hand turn over the city.

articles.title: Karni Mata Temple
articles.teaserText: A marble temple famous for 25,000 revered black rats that live in the temple who are considered the ancestors of Charans.

articles.title: Kijong-dong
articles.teaserText: A village in North Korea characterized by mainstream media as a North Korean propaganda Potemkin village.

articles.title: Korea Central Zoo
articles.teaserText: A zoo with such wondrous animals as a chimpanzee with a smoking habit, a parrot that sings the praises of Kim Il-sung, and some of the few legally owned dogs in Pyongyang.

articles.title: Kowloon Walled City
articles.teaserText: A former enclave in the city of Hong Kong, known for lawlessness and extremely cramped conditions before it was destroyed and turned into a park.

articles.title: Living root bridge
articles.teaserText: Double-decker suspension bridges formed of living plant aerial roots of rubber fig trees by tree shaping common in the southern part of the Northeast Indian state of Meghalaya.

articles.title: Love Land
articles.teaserText: An erotic-themed sculpture park on Jeju island in South Korea.

articles.title: Nahwa
articles.teaserText: One of only eight counter-enclaves (enclaves of enclaves).

articles.title: Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic
articles.teaserText: A landlocked exclave of Azerbaijan (it is surrounded by three different countries rather than only one, so it is not an enclave).

articles.title: Ōkunoshima
articles.teaserText: An island between the Japanese home islands of Honshu and Shikoku formerly home to a chemical weapons plant in WW2, now home to a huge population of feral but largely tame rabbits.

articles.title: Omsk Metro
articles.teaserText: A metro system with only one station and a total length of zero kilometres.

articles.title: Peanut Hole
articles.teaserText: A delightfully named patch of ocean in the Sea of Okhotsk that is totally surrounded by Russia's EEZ but not inside it. Often the subject of foreign overfishing.

articles.title: Rednaxela Terrace
articles.teaserText: A street in Hong Kong, whose name was reportedly reversed due to a clerical error

articles.title: Robot Building
articles.teaserText: That's not a giant robot looming in Bangkok; it's just a bank's headquarters

articles.title: Ryugyong Hotel
articles.teaserText: Once, it would have been the world's tallest hotel – except it lacked windows, fittings, or fixtures for over twenty years.

articles.title: San Serriffe
articles.teaserText: A lesser-known island in the Indian Ocean, subject of the April 1, 1977 Guardian.

articles.title: Sansha
articles.teaserText: A disputed prefecture-level city in Hainan consisting of a collection of atolls and reefs throughout the South China Sea.

articles.title: Seikan Tunnel Tappi Shakō Line
articles.teaserText: The closed funicular that connects an underground train station inside the Seikan Tunnel with a museum.

articles.title: Shingō, Aomori
articles.teaserText: A town in Japan that is (supposedly) home to the tomb of Jesus. The story behind the supposed tomb is even odder.

articles.title: Soʻx District
articles.teaserText: An exclave of Uzbekistan enclaved within Kyrgyzstan with a 99% Tajik population.

articles.title: Tashirojima
articles.teaserText: An island in Japan notable for being full of cats.

articles.title: Tomb of Suleyman Shah
articles.teaserText: One of the burial sites of the first Ottoman emperor's grandfather is part of Turkey despite being 27 kilometres (17 mi) south of the country's border with Syria.

articles.title: Tsu Station
articles.teaserText: By kana, the tersest railway station in Japan, serving the capital of an almost as terse prefecture. By stroke count, the tersest in the world. By transliteration, only second-tersest.

articles.title: Wonderland Amusement Park
articles.teaserText: The largest abandoned amusement park in Asia.

articles.title: X-Seed 4000
articles.teaserText: The tallest building ever designed, standing 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) tall and housing 500,000 to 1,000,000 people on 800 floors. It is, however, "never meant to be built".

articles.title: Yongning Pagoda
articles.teaserText: A 6th-century pagoda that was possibly the tallest structure in the world until it was destroyed by lightning 18 years after its completion.

articles.title: Zheltuga Republic
articles.teaserText: An illegal gold mining settlement that developed into a thriving unrecognised country, only surviving because the Chinese government was unaware that it existed.

articles.title: Argleton
articles.teaserText: A non-existent town in Lancashire, England that appeared on Google Maps.

articles.title: Barcelona Supercomputing Center
articles.teaserText: A supercomputer in a medieval chapel.

articles.title: Barentsburg
articles.teaserText: A completely Russian town, inhabited by Russians, with Russian buildings, supported financially by the Russian government, located in Norway.

articles.title: Barra Airport
articles.teaserText: An airport that only operates when the tide allows.

articles.title: Battersea Power Station station
articles.teaserText: A train station named after a non-train station.

articles.title: Beans and Bacon mine
articles.teaserText: With such little ventilation, visitors may want to avoid any source of ignition. Nearby mines are not to be outdone and have the following names: Mule Spinner, Frogs Hole, Cackle Mackle, and Wanton Legs.

articles.title: Berlin Brandenburg Airport
articles.teaserText: A construction-finished but unfinished in other areas airport in Berlin. Construction was finished in 2012; however, the opening date was repeatedly pushed back as the fire suppression system was installed incorrectly. It finally opened in October 2020.

articles.title: Bielefeld conspiracy
articles.teaserText: The Bielefeld-Verschwörung tries to hide the horrible truth about a city in Westphalia, Germany that doesn't exist... well, maybe.

articles.title: Brennender Berg
articles.teaserText: A German coal mine on fire since 1668.

articles.title: The Broomway
articles.teaserText: The most dangerous path in the world? Would you join a hundred others who died walking the invisible path?

articles.title: Brusio spiral viaduct
articles.teaserText: The title says it all, really.

articles.title: Büsingen am Hochrhein
articles.teaserText: A German town that is fully contained within Switzerland.

articles.title: Butt Hole Road
articles.teaserText: A tiny residential street in the UK that was so infamous for its name that it became a tourist attraction.

articles.title: Carpatho-Ukraine
articles.teaserText: The third shortest-lived state in history (see Benin Republic in Nigeria); it was independent for only 24 hours.

articles.title: Cerne Abbas Giant
articles.teaserText: An indecent chalk man in the English countryside.

articles.title: Ferdinand Cheval
articles.teaserText: A postman, who, for thirty-three years, collected stones while making his rounds and used them to build a surreal Palais Idéal ("Ideal Palace") of astonishing proportions and intricate detail.

articles.title: Colletto Fava
articles.teaserText: A 1,500-metre (4,900 ft) hill with a 61-metre (200 ft) stuffed pink bunny on top.

articles.title: Ebenezer Place, Wick
articles.teaserText: The world's shortest street.

articles.title: Fallen Monument Park
articles.teaserText: A Russian park best known for its toppled statues.

articles.title: Ferdinandea Island
articles.teaserText: The island that disappeared. And rose again. And sank again. And rose again. And sank again.

articles.title: Flannan Isles Lighthouse
articles.teaserText: Located on Eilean Mór, this lighthouse to the west of Scotland is the subject of an enduring mystery over the disappearance of its keepers in 1900.

articles.title: Forest swastika
articles.teaserText: A gigantic swastika made of larch trees that went unnoticed for nearly sixty years.

articles.title: Gammalsvenskby
articles.teaserText: A Swedish village, populated by Swedes, who speak an ancient Swedish dialect, in Ukraine.

articles.title: Gropecunt Lane
articles.teaserText: A street name found in English towns and cities during the Middle Ages.

articles.title: Icelandic Phallological Museum
articles.teaserText: A museum in Iceland solely devoted to the collection of penis specimens and penis-related art.

articles.title: JASON reactor
articles.teaserText: The only nuclear reactor in a 17th-century building.

articles.title: Leaning Tower of Suurhusen
articles.teaserText: Beating the world-famous Leaning Tower of Pisa by 1.22 degrees.

articles.title: List of destroyed landmarks in Spain
articles.teaserText: Over 60 interesting buildings, including larger castles, royal palaces, leaning towers, city gates which were completely or partially demolished and no longer exist, with their respective articles and images.

articles.title: Llandegley International Airport
articles.teaserText: When is an international airport not an international airport? When it's not an airport at all.

articles.title: Llanfairpwllgwyngyll
articles.teaserText: Or Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch, if you want to get technical.

articles.title: Magic Roundabout
articles.teaserText: Only in the United Kingdom would you find a large roundabout with six mini-roundabouts. (Not to be confused with the "Magic Roundabout"s in Colchester, Swindon or High Wycombe – or, for that matter, this "Magic Roundabout".)

articles.title: Märket
articles.teaserText: A lighthouse built on this island led to a redefinition of the border between Sweden and Finland.

articles.title: Metro-2
articles.teaserText: A purported secret metro line in Moscow.

articles.title: Monte Kaolino
articles.teaserText: A ski resort without snow.

articles.title: Mount Athos
articles.teaserText: An autonomous polity in Greece home to 20 monasteries, notable for being the only political subdivision in the world in which women (as well as female animals) are prohibited from entering for any reason.

articles.title: Municipalities of Liechtenstein
articles.teaserText: The blotchy, angular borders between these divisions seem almost arbitrarily strange. The UAE's are similarly weird.

articles.title: Neutral Moresnet
articles.teaserText: A tiny European region – approximately 1.4 square miles (3.6 km2) – that existed for a century as neutral territory between Germany and Belgium.

articles.title: Newhaven Marine railway station
articles.teaserText: A railway station that was technically open between 2006 and 2020, despite (a) no passenger trains serving the station during that time, (b) an inability to buy tickets to the station and (c) the station itself being demolished in 2017.

articles.title: Other World Kingdom
articles.teaserText: A micronation and BDSM resort whose ultimate goal is "absolute matriarchy" – for all men to be enslaved by women.

articles.title: Papa Westray Airport
articles.teaserText: An unassuming coastal airport in the Orkney Isles, where you can take a scenic flight to the nearby island of Westray, and enjoy all 47 seconds to 1 minute and 30 seconds of it.

articles.title: Paradiskullen
articles.teaserText: A ski jumping hill with a landing area that goes under one of Sweden's busiest railroads.

articles.title: Pheasant Island
articles.teaserText: An uninhabited river island which switches sovereignty between France and Spain every six months.

articles.title: Principality of Sealand
articles.teaserText: A micronation located 6 miles (9.7 km) off the coast of Suffolk, England whose population rarely exceeds ten.

articles.title: Reality Checkpoint
articles.teaserText: A lamppost with its own name.

articles.title: Röstigraben
articles.teaserText: The "Coarsely Grated Potato Ditch" in Switzerland, dividing Swiss-German and Swiss-French cuisine.

articles.title: Saatse Boot
articles.teaserText: A piece of Russian territory through which a 900-metre (3,000 ft) stretch of Estonian road passes. Although people are allowed to drive on the road without a permit or visa, it is prohibited to travel on foot, or to stop the vehicle for any reason.

articles.title: Schwerbelastungskörper
articles.teaserText: A piece of Nazi architecture in Berlin, built with the sole purpose of being heavy.

articles.title: Scottish Court in the Netherlands
articles.teaserText: A former Dutch NATO base called Camp Zeist was briefly ceded to Scotland to enable the trial of the Pan Am Flight 103 bombers.

articles.title: Sedlec Ossuary
articles.teaserText: A Christian chapel decorated by the bones of approximately 40,000 people.

articles.title: Sexi (Phoenician colony)
articles.teaserText: An ancient ruins, also known as Sex or Ex, with several Roman-era suburbs, including Pænis, Socordia and Villa Fatuus Maximus.

articles.title: Shell Grotto, Margate
articles.teaserText: A grotto with a mosaic of 4.6 million seashells, hidden underneath a backyard. Nobody knows who built it, when, or for what purpose.

articles.title: Smallest House in Great Britain
articles.teaserText: Only 5.49 square metres (59.1 sq ft) in size, in North Wales.

articles.title: Sovereign Military Order of Malta
articles.teaserText: A sovereign state with no land? How is that possible?

articles.title: Spreuerhofstraße
articles.teaserText: The world's narrowest street.

articles.title: Svalbard Global Seed Vault
articles.teaserText: If a global famine occurs, you better hope you live in Svalbard.

articles.title: Uffington White Horse
articles.teaserText: A giant chalk figure that has to be hit with hammers regularly to maintain it.

articles.title: UFO-Memorial Ängelholm
articles.teaserText: A memorial to a reputed UFO landing in Sweden.

articles.title: Unst Bus Shelter
articles.teaserText: The only of its kind on the island of Unst, Shetland. It is periodically refurnished and contains a sofa and TV.

articles.title: Vennbahn
articles.teaserText: A disused railway in Belgium which separates five pieces of Germany from the rest of Germany.

articles.title: Weißwurstäquator
articles.teaserText: The "White Sausage Equator" in Germany.

articles.title: White's
articles.teaserText: London's oldest and most famous gentleman's club had several famous people as members, including King Charles III, Prince William, former prime minister David Cameron and so on. The club is pretty much top secret, so yes, the English illuminati definitely aren't lurking and drinking tea there. Also, no girls are allowed.

articles.title: Whip-Ma-Whop-Ma-Gate
articles.teaserText: And the best street name has to go to this street in York, England. Also said to be the shortest street in the city too!

articles.title: Wooden Spoons Museum
articles.teaserText: A museum with the largest collection of wooden spoons in the world, ranging from 3,500 to over 6,000. Ladles and 500 erasers can also be found!

articles.title: Željava Air Base
articles.teaserText: An abandoned air base, located on the border between Croatia and Bosnia, that's almost entirely underground.

articles.title: 33 Thomas Street
articles.teaserText: A windowless skyscraper in New York and suspected NSA mass surveillance hub. Not suspicious at all.

articles.title: Agloe, New York
articles.teaserText: A fictional town in New York. Originally a phantom settlement, created as a copyright trap for a mapmaker, that ended up developing into an actual landmark.

articles.title: Alcohol and Drug Abuse Lake
articles.teaserText: Supposedly named after the treatment center nearby.

articles.title: Aroma of Tacoma
articles.teaserText: "What an incredible smell you've discovered" could have been this Washington city's motto.

articles.title: Aquarius Reef Base
articles.teaserText: A real-live underwater labolatory.

articles.title: Badlands Guardian
articles.teaserText: A natural topographic feature in Alberta, Canada, which, when viewed from above, looks remarkably like a human wearing a Native American headdress and earbuds.

articles.title: Beatosu and Goblu
articles.teaserText: Two non-existent towns that appeared on Michigan's official highway map as a reference to the University of Michigan and its rival, Ohio State University.

articles.title: Bubbly Creek
articles.teaserText: The branch of the Chicago River that was so contaminated with blood from the Stock Yards that it gained this appetizing moniker.

articles.title: Bullfrog County, Nevada
articles.teaserText: A former county in Nevada established around a mountain which was to become a radioactive waste disposal site. As of 2022, it is the only uninhabited county-equivalent to ever be created in the United States.

articles.title: Canusa Street
articles.teaserText: A road that's in both Canada and USA.

articles.title: Capitol Hill's mystery soda machine
articles.teaserText: A machine that offered rare drinks and nobody knows who operated it. It was in operation from the 1990s to 2018, when it disappeared and a note was left saying: “Went for a walk”.

articles.title: Cat Girl Manor
articles.teaserText: A manor described as "the Playboy Mansion of the kitten play community".

articles.title: Centralia, Pennsylvania
articles.teaserText: A town that's been on fire since 1962.

articles.title: Clinton Road (New Jersey)
articles.teaserText: In addition to having the longest traffic light in the country, the road is also notorious for reported occurrences of paranormal activity.

articles.title: Colma, California
articles.teaserText: A town where the dead outnumber the living by 1000 to 1.

articles.title: Corporation Trust Center (CT Corporation)
articles.teaserText: A small single-story building where over 285,000 companies, or over 15% of all companies in the United States, are legally based.

articles.title: Crush, Texas
articles.teaserText: A temporary "city" established as the site of an 1896 publicity stunt, a staged train wreck. The wreck unexpectedly caused two deaths and numerous injuries among spectators.

articles.title: Dixie Square Mall
articles.teaserText: A shopping mall that stood abandoned for over twice as long as it was in business until it was finally demolished in 2012. It was featured in the 1980 film The Blues Brothers and became a popular target for urban explorers.

articles.title: Dorset, Minnesota
articles.teaserText: A town that, on multiple occasions, has had a child as their "mayor".

articles.title: Dude Chilling Park
articles.teaserText: Originally a sign placed in a Vancouver park as a prank, now officially recognized public art.

articles.title: Ernst Thälmann Island
articles.teaserText: An island off the coast of Cuba that was (sort of) ceded to East Germany and thus (sort of) remains part of East Germany, which doesn't exist anymore (sort of).

articles.title: Fenelon Place Elevator
articles.teaserText: The shortest and steepest railroad in the world, (supposedly) located in a town of around 60,000 people.

articles.title: Florence Y'all Water Tower
articles.teaserText: A Northern Kentucky town's unique "welcome" sign.

articles.title: Gann Valley, South Dakota
articles.teaserText: The county seat of Buffalo County, South Dakota, despite nearby Fort Thompson having a population more than 90 times larger than Gann Valley.

articles.title: Greater Green River Intergalactic Spaceport
articles.teaserText: Consists entirely of a deeply rutted unmanned strip of soil/gravel and a windsock.

articles.title: Gum Wall
articles.teaserText: A brick wall in Seattle burdened by chewing gum. Cleaned in 2015, only to be turned into a memorial for Paris.

articles.title: Hans Island
articles.teaserText: A deserted Arctic island fought over by Canada and the Kingdom of Denmark for decades. The 2022 settlement created a land border between a North American and a European country.

articles.title: Hawaii 2
articles.teaserText: A quaint island in Maine purchased by Cards Against Humanity in 2014.

articles.title: Hess Triangle
articles.teaserText: This used to be part of a bigger plot of land but a road destroyed it but the planners couldn't plan correctly so it left this piece of land.

articles.title: Horace Burgess's Treehouse
articles.teaserText: A tree house built by a minister who claimed to have received a vision from God.

articles.title: Interstate 180 (Wyoming)
articles.teaserText: An Interstate Highway that isn't really a freeway at all.

articles.title: Interstate 19
articles.teaserText: The only U.S. highway marked in metric units, a relic of a historical push for metrication.

articles.title: Island of California
articles.teaserText: The third-largest U.S. state was formerly an island – at least on paper.

articles.title: Island of the Dolls
articles.teaserText: Located in Mexico City, this is an island full of broken and deteriorated dolls of various styles and colors, originally placed by the former owner of the island.

articles.title: Jackass Flats
articles.teaserText: The aptly named test site for the world's first and only nuclear-powered rocket engines.

articles.title: Jerimoth Hill
articles.teaserText: The highest natural point in Rhode Island. For years, one of the toughest highpoints in the U.S. to scale, not because of its 812-foot (247 m) height, but because of an angry old man who lived nearby.

articles.title: Just Room Enough Island
articles.teaserText: This island is about one-thirteenth of an acre in size but that didn't stop the Sizeland family from building a house on it.

articles.title: Landsat Island
articles.teaserText: A lonesome island with a frankly humorous tale.

articles.title: London Bridge
articles.teaserText: An over century year old authentic English bridge...that now resides in the middle of the desert.

articles.title: M-185 (Michigan highway)
articles.teaserText: The only state highway in the country that bans motor vehicles. It's also the only state highway to not have an accident until 2005.

articles.title: Mary Ellis grave
articles.teaserText: A grave that found itself in the middle of a movie theater parking lot.

articles.title: Michigan left
articles.teaserText: Directions are more complicated in Michigan.

articles.title: Mickey pylon
articles.teaserText: A powerline pylon with a shape reminiscent of a certain fictional rodent.

articles.title: Mill Ends Park
articles.teaserText: The smallest park in the world – 452 in2 (0.292 m2) – in Portland, Oregon.

articles.title: Mojave phone booth
articles.teaserText: A public phone booth that stood for several decades in the middle of a desert, miles away from any roads or other structures.

articles.title: Mollie's Nipple
articles.teaserText: The name of multiple places in Utah.

articles.title: Monowi
articles.teaserText: A village in Nebraska with a population of one. Hi, Elsie!

articles.title: Murder Kroger
articles.teaserText: A supermarket with a dark story.

articles.title: National Raisin Reserve
articles.teaserText: Created after World War II to control raisin prices. Run by the Raisin Administrative Committee, of course.

articles.title: Nettilling Lake
articles.teaserText: Located on Baffin Island, Nunavut, Canada. It's the largest lake on an island and also contains the largest lake on an island on a lake on an island, which in turn contains the world's largest island in a lake on an island in a lake on an island.

articles.title: Nitt Witt Ridge
articles.teaserText: A house in California, built out of beer cans, abalone shells, car parts, and other garbage previously tossed out by local residents, is now a historic landmark.

articles.title: Plymouth, Montserrat
articles.teaserText: A national capital with zero population.

articles.title: Pig Beach
articles.teaserText: A place where you can swim with pigs.

articles.title: Point Roberts, Washington
articles.teaserText: When defining international boundaries, sometimes a straight line isn't the best solution.

articles.title: Polar Bear Holding Facility
articles.teaserText: A prison for polar bears.

articles.title: Prada Marfa, Texas
articles.teaserText: For your luxury shopping bug, a Prada store in the desert.

articles.title: Rabbit Hash, Kentucky
articles.teaserText: A town whose mayors, since 1998, have all been dogs.

articles.title: Raising of Chicago
articles.teaserText: During the 1850s, the city was raised on jacks, building by building.

articles.title: Republic of Indian Stream
articles.teaserText: An area of land in northern New Hampshire that was an independent country from 1832 to 1835.

articles.title: Republic of Molossia
articles.teaserText: A 34-person micronation in Nevada which takes the meaning of the phrase "a man's home is his castle" to new extremes.

articles.title: Río Rico, Tamaulipas
articles.teaserText: A city that was ceded by the United States to Mexico in 1977 due to an earlier diversion of the Rio Grande.

articles.title: Rock N Roll McDonald's
articles.teaserText: A rock 'n roll-themed McDonald's restaurant located in Chicago, famous for being the subject of a song by outsider musician Wesley Willis.

articles.title: Rough and Ready, California
articles.teaserText: A currently populated, unincorporated mining town in the United States that seceded from the Union in 1850, forming the "Great Republic of Rough and Ready". Secession was rescinded less than three months later when its citizens noticed that they could not celebrate U.S. independence.

articles.title: Santa Claus, Arizona
articles.teaserText: In Mohave County, visit an abandoned tourist trap deep in the desert where Santa Claus, of all people, allegedly resides!

articles.title: Sam Kee Building
articles.teaserText: Known as the world's narrowest commercial building.

articles.title: S.N.P.J., Pennsylvania
articles.teaserText: A municipality consisting solely of a Slovenian fraternity's recreation center, established (in part) to get around liquor laws.

articles.title: Spiral Island
articles.teaserText: An artificial island, now destroyed, built from thousands of empty floating plastic bottles.

articles.title: State of Scott
articles.teaserText: Scott County in northern Tennessee seceded and formed its own state in opposition to Tennessee joining the Confederacy. It remained this way for over a century until it rejoined Tennessee in 1986.

articles.title: Texas State Highway 165
articles.teaserText: The only state highway in the country specifically designated to serve a cemetery...and nothing more. It's also the only state highway in the country to be partially closed every night.

articles.title: Tower of Wooden Pallets
articles.teaserText: Now replaced by an apartment building, its site remains City of Los Angeles Historic Cultural Monument no. 184.

articles.title: Track 61 (New York City)
articles.teaserText: A secret train platform located below the Waldorf Astoria New York designed for use by U.S. Presidents when they would visit the hotel.

articles.title: U Thant Island
articles.teaserText: An island in the East River with a surprisingly in-depth history for only being 2,000 square feet (190 m2) in area.

articles.title: Truth or Consequences, New Mexico
articles.teaserText: A New Mexico town that chose to rename itself after the Truth or Consequences game show in 1950, then never bothered changing back.

articles.title: War of the Roses
articles.teaserText: The historical rivalry between Lancaster and York. Not to be confused with Wars of the Roses, the historical rivalry between Lancaster and York.

articles.title: Wedge
articles.teaserText: It's harder than you think to construct the state of Delaware with a ruler and compass.

articles.title: Whittier, Alaska
articles.teaserText: A city in Alaska where (almost) all of its residents live in one building: Begich Towers.

articles.title: Winchester Mystery House
articles.teaserText: A house believed to be haunted by the ghosts of individuals killed by Winchester rifles.

articles.title: World's littlest skyscraper
articles.teaserText: The result of a fraudulent investment scheme, it's a four-story brick building constructed in 1920 in downtown Wichita Falls, Texas that has only one room on each of its four floors.

articles.title: Zilwaukee, Michigan
articles.teaserText: "Is this Milwaukee?" "Uh...yeah, it sure is!"

articles.title: Zone of Death
articles.teaserText: The part of Yellowstone National Park in Idaho, where any crime can technically be committed without punishment – but don't tempt fate!

articles.title: American Samoa
articles.teaserText: Despite having a functional legislature (the Fono) and a population of 46,366, American Samoa is considered an 'unincorporated unorganized' territory. It is also the only U.S. territory where people are not automatically born citizens, despite much of the population being involved in the military.

articles.title: Baldwin Street
articles.teaserText: A short suburban road in Dunedin, New Zealand, reputedly the world's steepest street.

articles.title: Ball's Pyramid
articles.teaserText: A nearly 600-metre-tall (2,000 ft) stone stack in the middle of the ocean.

articles.title: Banjawarn Station
articles.teaserText: Did a Japanese apocalypse cult test a nuke in the middle of rural Australia?

articles.title: Bayswater Subway
articles.teaserText: Bridge in Perth that has been hit by trucks 50 times between 2014 and 2020.

articles.title: Burning Mountain
articles.teaserText: A straightforwardly named mountain that has been on fire for over 6000 years.

articles.title: Cardrona Bra Fence
articles.teaserText: An eccentric tourist attraction in New Zealand.

articles.title: Coober Pedy
articles.teaserText: A mining town where most of the residents live underground.

articles.title: Egmont National Park
articles.teaserText: This national park's boundaries created a circular forest.

articles.title: Horizontal Falls
articles.teaserText: This pair of Australian "waterfalls" appear to be falling straight across the land.

articles.title: Hunga Tonga
articles.teaserText: An island that was created in 2015 after a volcano erupted between two islands and connected them.

articles.title: Jellyfish Lake
articles.teaserText: A lake where jellyfish have evolved without stingers due to a lack of predators.

articles.title: Jervis Bay Territory
articles.teaserText: Briefly ceded to the ACT to give it access to the sea despite not bordering the ACT.

articles.title: Kalawao County, Hawaii
articles.teaserText: The second-least populous county in the United States (after Loving County, Texas), with a population of 90 as of the 2010 United States Census. Established as a leper colony in 1866, it occupies a peninsula on Molokai and is not connected by road to the rest of the island.

articles.title: Kingman Reef
articles.teaserText: It's designated as its own US overseas territory despite having an area of only 0.03 square kilometres (0.012 sq mi) and being almost entirely underwater during low tide.

articles.title: Macquarie Island
articles.teaserText: The only place on earth where rocks from the Earth's mantle get exposed to the surface.

articles.title: Montague Street Bridge
articles.teaserText: A bridge in Melbourne that has had so many trucks crash into it and get stuck under it, the government used millions of dollars to install prevention measures (it did nothing).

articles.title: Mount Wycheproof
articles.teaserText: Considered a mountain when only 43 metres (141 ft) above surrounding terrain and 143 metres (469 ft) above sea level. There are parts of Sydney which have a higher elevation and are not considered a mountain.

articles.title: Murray Valley Highway
articles.teaserText: A 671-kilometre (417 mi) road that has a road route number of B400 for 668 kilometres (415 mi) in the Victorian section and unmarked for 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) in the New South Wales section making the Victorian road network not connected to the New South Wales Network in that area.

articles.title: Nelson–Blenheim notional railway
articles.teaserText: A road that was officially considered to be a railway by the New Zealand Government for 22 years.

articles.title: Pitcairn Islands
articles.teaserText: A British Overseas Territory where the entire population is Seventh-day Adventist and descended from the mutineers from the HMS Bounty. The entire population moved to Norfolk Island for three years in the 1850s and is currently at risk of going extinct due to the high number of emigrants.

articles.title: Palmyra Atoll
articles.teaserText: The United States' only 'incorporated unorganized' territory, despite there being no government and virtually no permanent residents for the Constitution to apply to...

articles.title: New Zealand State Highway 78
articles.teaserText: A road in Timaru, New Zealand, that is designated a highway despite being only 900 metres (3,000 ft) long.

articles.title: Pink Lake
articles.teaserText: A lake that is naturally pink, but suddenly turned blue in 2010.

articles.title: Princes Freeway (east)
articles.teaserText: A freeway with houses, traffic lights, and a 60-kilometre-per-hour (37 mph) limit in some areas. What are VicRoads thinking?

articles.title: Sandy Island
articles.teaserText: An island which was shown on Google Maps satellite view until 2012 despite not existing.

articles.title: That Wanaka Tree
articles.teaserText: A tree named after a hashtag on Instagram.

articles.title: Taumata
articles.teaserText: With a full name consisting of 85 characters, this hill may be the longest place name in the world.

articles.title: Te Urewera
articles.teaserText: A forested area in New Zealand that is also a legal person (see below).

articles.title: Whanganui River
articles.teaserText: A river in New Zealand that is legally a person.

articles.title: Wedding Cake Rock
articles.teaserText: A rock that looks exactly like a wedding cake.

articles.title: Whangamōmona
articles.teaserText: A self-declared republic in New Zealand, whose past presidents include a goat and a poodle.

articles.title: Americana, São Paulo
articles.teaserText: A town in Brazil founded by Confederate farmers and soldiers in the aftermath of the American Civil War.

articles.title: Darién Gap
articles.teaserText: This journey is impossible with the modes you have selected.

articles.title: Devil's Island
articles.teaserText: A notorious penal colony off the coast of French Guiana.

articles.title: Fordlândia
articles.teaserText: The man himself was not without his abject failures in Brazil.

articles.title: Hacienda Nápoles
articles.teaserText: The luxurious estate of the deceased drug lord Pablo Escobar that may lead to an invasive hippopotamus population in Colombia.

articles.title: Isla Apipé
articles.teaserText: An Argentine island in the Paraná River surrounded by Paraguayan waters.

articles.title: Lençóis Maranhenses National Park
articles.teaserText: Wait, deserts don't seasonally flood. They just don't. Or do they?

articles.title: Nazca Lines
articles.teaserText: A line museum, exhibited outdoors in southern Peru.

articles.title: Abul-Abbas
articles.teaserText: An Asian elephant given to Carolingian emperor Charlemagne by the Abbasid caliph Harun al-Rashid.

articles.title: Architecture terrible
articles.teaserText: An architectural style advocated by French architect Jacques-François Blondel.

articles.title: John Bentinck, 5th Duke of Portland
articles.teaserText: A reclusive English nobleman who built a vast maze under his home.

articles.title: Burned house horizon
articles.teaserText: The horizon which consumed cultures in the Balkans and around the Black Sea.

articles.title: Cadaver Synod
articles.teaserText: A deceased Pope was exhumed and put on trial!

articles.title: Charles II of Spain
articles.teaserText: The last Habsburg King of Spain, who was so inbred that he could barely rule his nation.

articles.title: Confederados
articles.teaserText: A small group of white Brazilians with roots in the southern United States.

articles.title: Cottage cheese boycott
articles.teaserText: A protest against rising staple food prices in Israel.

articles.title: Count of St. Germain
articles.teaserText: The original Tommy Wiseau, an eighteenth century polymath who made a number of contradictory claims about his origins, including that he was 500 years old. People have also claimed he is an important theosophical figure who many have claimed to have met years after his supposed death in 1784.

articles.title: Crocker Land Expedition
articles.teaserText: An expedition to a non-existent island created to swindle a businessman.

articles.title: Czechoslovak Togo
articles.teaserText: A landlocked Eastern European country proposed getting a colony in Africa, to be administered by its troops in Siberia.

articles.title: Dai Hong Dan incident
articles.teaserText: The time the United States and North Korea teamed up against their greatest fear... pirates!

articles.title: Dancing plague of 1518
articles.teaserText: In 1518 around 400 people took to dancing for days without rest, and, over the period of about one month, some of those affected died of heart attack, stroke, or exhaustion.

articles.title: Daughter of Emperor Xiaoming of Northern Wei
articles.teaserText: A disputed first female monarch of Chinese history before Wu Zetian, whom the Empress Dowager Hu declared was a boy and was emperor for a day before being replaced by another infant.

articles.title: Timothy Dexter
articles.teaserText: Genius businessman or loony?

articles.title: Đorđe Martinović incident
articles.teaserText: Perhaps, one of the motives that started the fragmentation of Yugoslavia. We are serious.

articles.title: Defenestrations of Prague
articles.teaserText: When was the last time throwing someone out of a window started a war?

articles.title: Erfurt latrine disaster
articles.teaserText: It's incredible how quickly someone's life can go to shit.

articles.title: Juan Pujol García
articles.teaserText: A spy who worked as a double agent for the Nazis and the United Kingdom during World War II.

articles.title: Glass delusion
articles.teaserText: Believing oneself to be made of glass was quite in vogue among Renaissance-era European nobility.

articles.title: Great Michigan Pizza Funeral
articles.teaserText: "Ashes to ashes, crust to crust."

articles.title: Great Molasses Flood
articles.teaserText: A storage tank burst and flooded the streets of Boston with a 25-foot (7.6 m) high wave of molasses.

articles.title: Great Moon Hoax
articles.teaserText: An infamous article by The Sun that claimed that animals such as unicorns and bat-winged humans were found living on the moon.

articles.title: Great Stink
articles.teaserText: A London summer so smelly it prompted government action.

articles.title: Violet Jessop
articles.teaserText: An Argentinian nurse known for surviving three separate maritime disasters, including the sinkings of both the Titanic and the Britannic.

articles.title: Gregor MacGregor
articles.teaserText: That's his real name. Possibly the only honest thing about him.

articles.title: London Beer Flood
articles.teaserText: Nine people drowned by a flood of over 300,000 gallons of beer.

articles.title: The Miracle of 1511
articles.teaserText: When the people of Brussels protested against their rulers by building satirical and pornographic snowmen.

articles.title: Mutiny on the Bounty
articles.teaserText: The true story starting with a stern captain and a lustful crew on a Royal Navy ship and ending with the British-Polynesian Seventh-day Adventist culture of the Pitcairn Islands. Plenty of drama in-between.

articles.title: Kilroy Was Here
articles.teaserText: A meme from World War II.

articles.title: Kottabos
articles.teaserText: The world's first drinking game. Care to play? All you need is a bronze "lamp stand" with a tiny statuette on top and some wine.

articles.title: Kingdom of Sedang
articles.teaserText: A French adventurer created a kingdom in Vietnam.

articles.title: North Hollywood shootout
articles.teaserText: In 1997, two heavily armed men were involved in a bank robbery, which turned into a 44-minute shootout with police officers. 20 people were injured as a result, and only the criminals died.

articles.title: Norwegian butter crisis
articles.teaserText: A massive inflation of butter prices caused illegal smuggling and an "emergency appeal" from a Danish television show.

articles.title: Emilio Palma
articles.teaserText: An Argentine national who was the first person to be born in Antarctica.

articles.title: Pepsi fruit juice flood
articles.teaserText: A PepsiCo warehouse collapse flooded the streets of Russia with an assortment of juices.

articles.title: George Psalmanazar
articles.teaserText: A Frenchman who was so successful in convincing 18th-century Britain he was a Taiwanese man, that he wrote an elaborate and blatantly fictitious history of the island.

articles.title: Mathias Rust
articles.teaserText: The West German who landed on a bridge in Moscow in 1987.

articles.title: Order of the Pug
articles.teaserText: A fraternal order that existed for Roman Catholics in Bavaria in the 18th century.

articles.title: Puyi
articles.teaserText: He became the last Emperor of China at the age of two and died as an ordinary citizen, ending 2,133 years of dynastic rule in China. In his twilight years, he also did community theater.

articles.title: Pope Benedict IX
articles.teaserText: He became pope at twenty, and later sold the papacy. He was pope three times.

articles.title: Roland the Farter
articles.teaserText: He was granted land by King Henry II in exchange for annual flatulist performances.

articles.title: Sacred Band of Thebes
articles.teaserText: An elite fighting force consisting of a hand-picked groups of 150 pairs of male lovers.

articles.title: Taiping Rebellion
articles.teaserText: One of the most lethal wars in history centers around a Chinese man claiming to be the brother of Jesus Christ.

articles.title: Tank Man
articles.teaserText: An unidentified man who achieved widespread recognition after standing in front, and blocking the procession of a column of tanks, the morning after the bloody suppression of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.

articles.title: Uday Hussein
articles.teaserText: Saddam Hussein's oldest son and a real-life Far Cry or James Bond villain. Among other things, he was a rapist and murderer, had a doppelganger named Latif Yahia, (whom Uday would send to torture) and also had the habit of kidnapping women at wedding celebrations. He was killed along with his brother by US soldiers during the Occupation of Iraq (2003–2011); some may argue this was the only "good" thing that ever came from this war.

articles.title: Weather Station Kurt
articles.teaserText: That time when the Nazis landed in North America.

articles.title: William Walker (filibuster)
articles.teaserText: A lawyer and avid pro-slavery filibuster from the US who tried to conquer the northern part of Baja California, where he failed, and then was able to conquer the newly independent Nicaragua where he ended up as the de facto president for almost a year. He was ultimately expelled from the country and killed in Honduras, but his history contributed to the concept of Latin America.

articles.title: John Zegrus
articles.teaserText: A man who showed up in Japan in 1959 under a fake identity, claiming to be a war hero who was now working as an ambassador and spy from the fictional African nation of Negus Habes based in South Korea, looking to recruit Japanese soldiers to fight for the United Arab Republic. This implausible backstory has inspired a number of urban legends. His true identity and purpose for his visit remain unknown.

articles.title: All horses are the same color
articles.teaserText: Flawed mathematical induction proof that all horses are the same color.
Zero has a negative flavor in the worlds of computing, experimental science and statistical mechanics.
An infinitely long way to write 1.
...or perhaps it equals 1984...

articles.title: 616 (number)
articles.teaserText: The real number of the beast?

articles.title: Bertrand's postulate
articles.teaserText: Despite now being a theorem, still conventionally called a postulate.

articles.title: Belphegor's prime
articles.teaserText: 1 followed by 13 zeros followed by 666 followed by 13 zeros followed by 1.

articles.title: The Complexity of Songs
articles.teaserText: A treatise on the computational complexity of songs by venerable computer scientist Donald Knuth.

articles.title: Cox–Zucker machine
articles.teaserText: This machine does what?!

articles.title: Erdős–Bacon number
articles.teaserText: A combination of the degrees of separation from actor Kevin Bacon and mathematician Paul Erdős.

articles.title: Extravagant number
articles.teaserText: Don't take it shopping. Not very friendly with the frugal number either.

articles.title: Gabriel's horn
articles.teaserText: A geometric figure with an infinite surface area but finite volume. So even if the horn was filled with paint, you could never paint its surface.

articles.title: Happy number
articles.teaserText: Not just a cheery song on the radio.

articles.title: Hilbert's paradox of the Grand Hotel
articles.teaserText: A fully occupied hotel cannot accommodate any more guests. Or can it? Or, once it can, can it not?

articles.title: Graham's number
articles.teaserText: A number so large that the observable universe is not big enough to write it in full in decimal notation or even scientific notation.

articles.title: Illegal number
articles.teaserText: Does the US government forbid knowledge of the existence of certain numbers?

articles.title: Illumination Problem
articles.teaserText: A room with a bit of a shadow.

articles.title: Indiana Pi Bill
articles.teaserText: A notorious attempt to legislate the value of pi as 3.2.

articles.title: Infinite monkey theorem
articles.teaserText: An infinite number of monkeys typing on an infinite number of typewriters will (almost surely) produce all possible written texts.

articles.title: Interesting number paradox
articles.teaserText: Either all natural numbers are interesting or else none of them are.

articles.title: Legendre's constant
articles.teaserText: After 91 years and much effort, this legendary constant was found to be ... 1. Just 1.

articles.title: Look-and-say sequence
articles.teaserText: Also known as the Cuckoo's Egg.

articles.title: Mathematical fallacy
articles.teaserText: Trying to prove that 2 = 1 or that 1 < 0.

articles.title: Mathematical joke
articles.teaserText: Complex numbers are all fun and games until someone loses an i. That's when things get real.

articles.title: Minkowski's question-mark function
articles.teaserText: A function with an unusual notation and possessing unusual fractal properties.

articles.title: Monty Hall problem
articles.teaserText: The counter-intuitive way to prevail when playing Let's Make a Deal.

articles.title: Moving sofa problem
articles.teaserText: What is the largest area of a sofa that can be manoeuvred through an L-shaped corner?

articles.title: Narcissistic number
articles.teaserText: The pluperfect digital invariant says "Count me in"!

articles.title: Nothing-up-my-sleeve number
articles.teaserText: A number which is "above suspicion".

articles.title: Number of the beast
articles.teaserText: For beastly people bored of the number of unluckiness.

articles.title: Numbers station
articles.teaserText: [Six bars of The Lincolnshire Poacher play] "¡Atención! ¡Atención! One, four, seventeen, twenty-four..."

articles.title: Potato paradox
articles.teaserText: If potatoes consisting of 99% water dry so that they are 98% water, they lose 50% of their weight.

articles.title: Ramanujan summation
articles.teaserText: What do you get when you add all positive integers, up to infinity? You get a negative fraction.

articles.title: Spaghetti sort
articles.teaserText: An algorithm for sorting rods of spaghetti.

articles.title: Taxicab number
articles.teaserText: Never tell a Numberphile that a number is uninteresting.

articles.title: Tetraphobia
articles.teaserText: Sometimes found in conjunction with triskaidekaphobia (see below) in East Asian cultures. More prevalent in Japan, where 49 is associated with "suffering until death".

articles.title: Schizophrenic number
articles.teaserText: Can numbers have mental disorders?

articles.title: Sexy prime

articles.title: Six nines in pi
articles.teaserText: A mathematical coincidence, the sequence "999999" appears a mere 762 digits into the decimal expansion of pi.

articles.title: Titanic prime
articles.teaserText: Surprisingly, not discovered by Leonardo DiCaprio.

articles.title: Tits group
articles.teaserText: The perfect sporadic group doesn't exi-

articles.title: Triskaidekaphobia
articles.teaserText: No, it's not related to the Code of Hammurabi. No, it's not always considered unlucky. Yes, space exploration has been touched by it.

articles.title: Ulam spiral
articles.teaserText: A bored mathematician discovers an unusual numerical pattern while doodling.

articles.title: Umbral calculus
articles.teaserText: A mathematical method successfully used for over 100 years, despite the notable limitation of no one on Earth knowing exactly how or why it worked.

articles.title: Vampire number
articles.teaserText: Integers with real bite; some even have multiple pairs of fangs.

articles.title: Zenzizenzizenzic
articles.teaserText: You know how x3 is called "x cubed"? Well, x8 is called...

articles.teaserText: When moving an element from one set to another set raises – counter-intuitively – the average values of both sets. Also known as the Will Rogers paradox.

articles.teaserText: No more asking "So what time is it there?"

articles.teaserText: She followed her parents in the business of selling people Greenwich Mean Time.

articles.title: International Talk Like a Pirate Day
articles.teaserText: Shiver my timbers (a-harrr!) every September 19.

articles.title: List of non-standard dates
articles.teaserText: Including, among other things, January 0, February 30, and May 35.

articles.title: Manhattanhenge
articles.teaserText: Twice every year, the setting sun aligns with Manhattan's street grid.

articles.title: Mole Day
articles.teaserText: The Avogadro constant is celebrated on October 23rd starting at exactly 6:02 am.

articles.teaserText: A theory by Heribert Illig that the Early Middle Ages (614–911) never occurred. Therefore, it is now 1725 rather than 2022.

articles.teaserText: The day – March 14 – on which the constant π is celebrated.

articles.teaserText: A day in Japan celebrating long, thin biscuits. Due to their shape, it is celebrated on 11/11.

articles.title: Singles' Day
articles.teaserText: One is the loneliest number. 11/11 makes an appropriate date to celebrate being single.

articles.teaserText: May the 4th be with you.

articles.teaserText: Was there a year between 1 BC and AD 1?

articles.title: Year 2000 problem
articles.teaserText: A possible computing problem in the 1990's that was supposed to have occurred when the 21st century and 3rd millennium arrived. Of course, that never happened.

articles.title: Square Root Day
articles.teaserText: Any date when the day and month are both the square root of the last two digits of the year (the next being 5th May 2025).

articles.teaserText: May the 4th be with you.

articles.teaserText: In 1998, Swatch tried to reshape our timing system.

articles.teaserText: A Thanksgiving-Hanukkah hybrid when the two overlap in November in the US; maybe your Hanukkah present can be a Thanksgiving Dinner.

articles.title: Towel Day
articles.teaserText: Don't forget to bring a towel, terrible or otherwise.

articles.title: Singles' Day
articles.teaserText: One is the loneliest number. 11/11 makes an appropriate date to celebrate being single.

articles.title: Académie de la Carpette anglaise
articles.teaserText: A satirical French organisation that awards prizes to "members of the French élite who distinguish themselves by relentlessly promoting the domination of the English language over the French language in France and in European institutions".

articles.title: Andalusian language movement
articles.teaserText: A group of people have attempted to promote Andalusian Spanish as a distinct language. They have successfully created an Andalusian version of Minecraft.

articles.teaserText: A dispute over which typeface was more "German". At first, the Nazis were for Fraktur...

articles.teaserText: How do you make things look "old" in a constructed language? By inventing a new one!

articles.teaserText: A must-see for connoisseurs of gibberish.

articles.title:

buffalo Buffalo buffalo
articles.teaserText: A meaningful, grammatical construction that has inspired linguists to talk about bullying amongst Western New York's bison population.

articles.teaserText: A sentence contrived by Noam Chomsky to demonstrate that a sentence can be grammatical yet nonsensical.

articles.teaserText: More people have researched these nonsensical sentences than I have. [sic]

articles.teaserText: How a simple word can cause so much controversy.

articles.title: Chinese word for crisis
articles.teaserText: More notable among Americans than among the Chinese, apparently.

articles.teaserText: The secret language of identical twins, also called idioglossia.

articles.teaserText: The name of this measuring device can also mean idiot.

articles.teaserText: Sometimes people do dumb things.

articles.title: Duck test

articles.title: Engrish
articles.teaserText: Attempts by East Asian people – especially the Japanese – to construct English words and phrases.

articles.title: E-Prime
articles.teaserText: A form of English without the verb 'to be'.

articles.title: Eskimo words for snow
articles.teaserText: The claim that Eskimo languages have an unusually large number of words for "snow".

articles.title: Etaoin shrdlu
articles.teaserText: Cryptic echoes from the days of hot metal typesetting.

articles.teaserText: As good an argument as any for English-language spelling reform.

articles.teaserText: A way to greet those well-versed in rhetoric.

articles.teaserText: A dash between communism and independence.

articles.title: Jonathan
articles.teaserText: Oldest known living terrestrial animal in the world (if it weren't Adwaita). He made the reverse of the 5p of Saint Helena. What have you done?

articles.title: Jumbo
articles.teaserText: An elephant with gigantism.

articles.title: Khanzir
articles.teaserText: Possibly the world's loneliest pig. Even more lonely during the swine flu outbreak.

articles.title: Lily Flagg
articles.teaserText: A Jersey cow that produced record amounts of butter and got a sizable neighborhood named for her.

articles.title: Lin Wang
articles.teaserText: A Taiwanese elephant made famous for his participation in the Second Sino-Japanese War.

articles.title: Lion of Gripsholm Castle
articles.teaserText: What happens when you tell a taxidermist who doesn't know what a lion is to stuff and mount a lion.

articles.title: Lonesome George
articles.teaserText: The last known individual of the species Pinta Island tortoise. He was known as the rarest creature in the world.

articles.title: Mary
articles.teaserText: Makes the phrase "hung like an elephant" take on a whole new meaning.

articles.title: Mayor Max II
articles.teaserText: The world's cutest mayor-for-life creature: a Golden Retriever.

articles.title: Mike the Headless Chicken
articles.teaserText: A rooster that lived for 18 months with its head cut off.

articles.title: Ming
articles.teaserText: A ~500-year-old clam that was killed when scientists opened its shell to see how old it was.

articles.title: Nim Chimpsky
articles.teaserText: A chimpanzee, subject of long-running studies into animal language acquisition, named punningly for linguist Noam Chomsky.

articles.title: Osama bin Laden
articles.teaserText: An elusive elephant who terrorized the jungle of Assam. He was eventually shot, but there are those who question the official story of his death. Much like his famous namesake.

articles.title: Oscar the Cat
articles.teaserText: A hospice cat who was featured in the New England Journal of Medicine for his purported ability to predict the impending death of terminally ill patients.

articles.title: Owen and Mzee
articles.teaserText: Hippo and tortoise that befriended each other after the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami.

articles.title: Paul
articles.teaserText: A now-deceased psychic octopus who could predict the winner of football games, notably during the 2010 FIFA World Cup.

articles.title: Potoooooooo
articles.teaserText: Actually, it's pronounced "potatoes".

articles.title: Ravens of the Tower of London
articles.teaserText: Ravens used as soldiers in the Tower of London.

articles.title: River Thames whale
articles.teaserText: In 2006, a Northern Bottlenose swam into London and on to the front pages of the British newspapers.

articles.title: Sergeant Reckless
articles.teaserText: A horse that held an official rank in the US military, fought in the Korean War and participated in an amphibious landing.

articles.title: Stubbs
articles.teaserText: A cat who was the mayor of an Alaskan town for nearly 20 years.

articles.title: Tamworth Two
articles.teaserText: Two pigs who, in 1998, escaped an abattoir in England and attracted media attraction. Thanks to a newspaper, they were never made into bacon, ham or sausages.

articles.title: Tillamook Cheddar
articles.teaserText: The world's most successful and widely shown animal artist.

articles.title: Timothy
articles.teaserText: A tortoise that was present during the bombardment of Sevastopol during the Crimean War in 1854 and survived until 2004.

articles.title: Topsy
articles.teaserText: An elephant that was electrocuted, as the event was filmed by the Edison Manufacturing Company.

articles.title: Turra Coo
articles.teaserText: An insurance protest gone too far.

articles.title: Unsinkable Sam
articles.teaserText: A cat that has survived the sinking of three ships.

articles.title: Vacanti mouse
articles.teaserText: A mouse with a human ear on its back.

articles.title: William Windsor
articles.teaserText: A cashmere goat who served as a lance corporal in the 1st Battalion, the Royal Welsh, an infantry battalion of the British Army.

articles.title: Wojtek
articles.teaserText: A soldier of the 22nd Artillery Supply Company of the Polish II Corps who also happened to be a Syrian Brown Bear. He enjoyed beer and cigarettes.

articles.title: Anophthalmus hitleri
articles.teaserText: Rare blind beetle named after Adolf Hitler, poached by collectors of Hitler memorabilia.

articles.title: Aptostichus stephencolberti
articles.teaserText: A trapdoor spider named after Stephen Colbert. Naturally, because he asked for it.

articles.title: Bill Gates' flower fly
articles.teaserText: A flower fly, Eristalis gatesi, named after Bill Gates.

articles.title: Madidi titi monkey
articles.teaserText: A new species of monkey that was officially named after the GoldenPalace.com online casino.

articles.title: Harryplax
articles.teaserText: A genus of crab named in part after the titular character of the Harry Potter franchise. The sole species of this genus is named after the coldly hostile, yet emotion-concealing character from the same franchise.

articles.title: Mini
articles.teaserText: A genus of tiny Madagascar frogs containing 3 species: Mini ature, Mini mum, and Mini scule.

articles.title: Mothers against decapentaplegic
articles.teaserText: Actually, it's a protein.

articles.title: Mountain Chicken
articles.teaserText: Is it a frog or a chicken?

articles.title: Neopalpa donaldtrumpi
articles.teaserText: A moth remarkable for its orange head and small genitalia.

articles.title: Pachygnatha zappa
articles.teaserText: A spider whose abdominal markings resemble a very famous mustache

articles.title: Pikachurin
articles.teaserText: An extracellular matrix-like retinal protein named after Pikachu.

articles.title: Setaceous Hebrew character
articles.teaserText: A European moth with wing markings bearing a chance resemblance to a letter in the Hebrew alphabet.

articles.title: Spongiforma squarepantsii
articles.teaserText: A type of mushroom named after SpongeBob SquarePants.

articles.title: Strigiphilus garylarsoni
articles.teaserText: A biting louse named for cartoonist Gary Larson of Far Side fame.

articles.title: Synalpheus pinkfloydi
articles.teaserText: A species of snapping shrimp named after the famous English rock band.

articles.title: Thaumatodryinus tuukkaraski
articles.teaserText: A wasp named after NHL goaltender Tuukka Rask as both are acrobatic, and have a killer glove hand.

articles.title: Zombie taxon
articles.teaserText: Paleontology of the undead.

articles.title: Zoosphaerium darthvaderi
articles.teaserText: Named after Darth Vader, this one has an anal shield with a "pronounced bell shape"!

articles.title: Bialbero di Casorzo
articles.teaserText: A cherry tree that grows upon a mulberry tree in Italy.

articles.title: Chandelier Tree
articles.teaserText: A 300-foot-tall (91 m) redwood with a giant hole cut through the middle for cars to drive through.

articles.title: Echinopsis lageniformis
articles.teaserText: A cactus the Germans call Frauenglück, or "Women's Joy".

articles.title: Olympic oaks
articles.teaserText: Gifts from the Führer. Some are still alive.

articles.title: Moon tree
articles.teaserText: Trees planted from seeds that were taken into space by Apollo 14.

articles.title: Nepenthes lowii
articles.teaserText: A plant that lures animals to release their droppings into a pitcher.

articles.title: Mimosa pudica
articles.teaserText: A plant that rapidly closes or folds its leaves after they are touched.

articles.title: Old Man of the Lake
articles.teaserText: A 30-foot (9 m) tree stump that has been floating around Oregon's Crater Lake since at least 1896.

articles.title: Pando
articles.teaserText: An 80,000 year old quaking aspen colony that is believed to be one of the oldest and heaviest organisms on the planet.

articles.title: Plant arithmetic
articles.teaserText: Plants can do math!

articles.title: Plant rights
articles.teaserText: If other living beings like humans and animals can have rights, then why not plants?

articles.title: Pomato
articles.teaserText: It's both potato and tomato!

articles.title: Tendril perversion
articles.teaserText: A geometric phenomenon sometimes observed in helical structures like plant tendrils and telephone handset cords.

articles.title: Tree of Knowledge (Australia)
articles.teaserText: Killed by ignorance.

articles.title: Tree of Ténéré
articles.teaserText: A solitary acacia that was once the most isolated tree on Earth before being run over by a drunken Libyan truck driver.

articles.title: Tree That Owns Itself
articles.teaserText: Its owner loved it so much that he granted it ownership of itself.

articles.title: Antikythera mechanism
articles.teaserText: An analog computer built in Ancient Greece.

articles.title: Bird strike
articles.teaserText: Turns out that a bird hitting a plane at a high altitude can make quite a mess.

articles.title: Disgesting Duck
articles.teaserText: An automaton built to simulate a duck eating, digesting, and excreting.

articles.title: Centennial Light
articles.teaserText: A hundred-year-old light bulb that has been burning nonstop for 119 years.

articles.title: Clocky
articles.teaserText: An alarm clock that hides from its owner.

articles.title: Digital sundial
articles.teaserText: Unlike an analog sundial, a clock that indicates the current time with numerals formed by the sunlight striking it.

articles.title: Dreamachine
articles.teaserText: A device made with a light bulb and a record turntable that reportedly induces lucid dreaming. (And you thought the makers of Die Another Day made it up. There's still no news about invisible Aston Martin V12 Vanquishes.)

articles.title: Electronic voice phenomenon
articles.teaserText: Alleged spiritual voices heard in white noise and radio interference.

articles.title: Gun-powered mousetrap

articles.teaserText: Why it's always a bad idea to put the guy next door out of business if he has a ten-ton armor-plated bulldozer in his garage.

articles.title: History of perpetual motion machines
articles.teaserText: The concept has eluded and baffled the greatest minds for thousands of years – and will continue to elude anyone who tries to build one.

articles.title: Klerksdorp sphere
articles.teaserText: Spheres with three parallel grooves dated to be three billion years old... Evidence of ancient intelligent life? An unusual natural phenomenon? Who knows...

articles.title: List of inventors killed by their own invention
articles.teaserText: Perilous parachutes, lethal lighthouses and murderous motorcycles!

articles.title: Mosquito laser
articles.teaserText: A bug zapper with a difference.

articles.title: My Friend Cayla
articles.teaserText: That doll is a spy!

articles.title: One red paperclip
articles.teaserText: A man's small piece of metal turns out to be worth more than expected.

articles.title: Parking chair
articles.teaserText: Using household objects to reserve parking spaces.

articles.title: Pigeon photography
articles.teaserText: Pigeons were used by the Germans for aerial surveillance in World War I, and apparently also in World War II. Not to forget the CIA's own pigeon camera.

articles.title: Project Cybersyn
articles.teaserText: Chilean robo-socialism control chamber invented by a Brit with a gigantic beard.

articles.title: Pythagorean cup
articles.teaserText: When the cup is filled beyond a certain point, it will empty itself.

articles.title: Quartz crisis
articles.teaserText: Not a comic book story arc, but the upheaval in watchmaking caused by the introduction of quartz watches.

articles.title: Royal Mail rubber band
articles.teaserText: One billion are used every year and often seen littering the streets of UK cities.

articles.title: Russian floating nuclear power station
articles.teaserText: Self-contained, low-capacity, floating nuclear power plants.

articles.title: Splayd
articles.teaserText: 33.3% spoon, 33.3% knife, 33.3% fork.

articles.title: Spork
articles.teaserText: A cross between a spoon and a fork. Not to be confused with a knork.

articles.title: Tempest Prognosticator
articles.teaserText: Meteorology by frightened annelid.

articles.title: Turboencabulator
articles.teaserText: A device whose sole function is to expose technological ignorance.

articles.title: Uncanny valley
articles.teaserText: How to measure your emotional response to androids.

articles.title: Useless machine
articles.teaserText: In most cases, toys for adults.

articles.title: Wheat lamp
articles.teaserText: A type of lamp used by miners that is unrelated to wheat.

articles.title: Wrap rage
articles.teaserText: Ever been driven mad by packaging that just won't open?

articles.title: Xianxingzhe
articles.teaserText: A Chinese robot, according to the Japanese, that will save its country from corporate capitalism with its crotch cannon.

articles.teaserText: A 1970s organization whose campaign was to end pay toilets in the United States of America.

articles.title: Female urination device
articles.teaserText: Used by women when needing or wanting to pee standing up.

articles.title: Groom of the Stool
articles.teaserText: The most intimate Royal office.

articles.title: Hotel toilet-paper folding
articles.teaserText: Ever wondered why it was so?

articles.title: Interactive Urinal Communicator
articles.teaserText: A talking urinal made for advertising purposes.

articles.title: iLoo
articles.teaserText: Microsoft's attempt to bring you the interwebzzz inside the portable public loo.

articles.title: Japanese toilets
articles.teaserText: The most advanced toilets in the world with computers, nozzles and flashing lights.

articles.title: List of people who died on the toilet
articles.teaserText: You could say they died on the throne.

articles.title: Shit flow diagram
articles.teaserText: This is the technical term.

articles.title: Stainless steel soap
articles.teaserText: Metallic soap that removes odours from the hands.

articles.title: Toilet-related injuries and deaths
articles.teaserText: Not all injuries and deaths linked to toilets are urban legends.

articles.title: Toilet papering
articles.teaserText: Art or vandalism?

articles.teaserText: On the pros and cons of letting toilet paper hang over or under the roll.

articles.teaserText: A fake penis used to beat drug tests (complete with dried urine, heater, syringe). Comes in white, tan, Latino, brown, and black

articles.title: World Toilet Day
articles.teaserText: International holiday declared by the United Nations.

articles.title: The dress
articles.teaserText: The biggest question of 2015: Is it white and gold or black and blue?

articles.title: Fatsuit
articles.teaserText: Yes, this makes you look fat.

articles.title: Gorilla suit
articles.teaserText: What to wear when you don't want to look human.

articles.title: Koteka
articles.teaserText: An unusual traditional garment of western New Guinea, also known as the "penis gourd".

articles.title: Muffin top
articles.teaserText: A marketing mishap, many well-meaning young women, and vanity came together to form this demographic.

articles.title: Shoe tossing
articles.teaserText: The practice of throwing footwear, whether for humorous or political purposes.

articles.title: Sweater curse
articles.teaserText: Think your loved one will be pleased if you knit them a sweater? Think again.

articles.title: Three Wolf Moon
articles.teaserText: A T-shirt with wolves howling at the moon that gained popularity after one person wrote a parodic review for it on Amazon.com.

articles.title: Tin foil hat
articles.teaserText: Headgear which allegedly prevents a person from having their minds read or controlled.

articles.teaserText: Two Japan Airlines aircraft were roughly 135 m (443 ft) away from causing the deadliest aviation accident in history.

articles.title: 2003 Angola 727 disappearance
articles.teaserText: A Boeing 727 was stolen, with at least two people aboard, and never found.

articles.title: 2018 Horizon Air Q400 incident
articles.teaserText: A ground service agent with no flight experience whatsoever managed to do insanely difficult aerial maneuvers in a stolen plane that was thought to be impossible to do those maneuvers in.

articles.title: Aeroflot Flight 593
articles.teaserText: A plane that crashed because the pilot let his kids fly it.

articles.title: Aeroflot Flight 6502
articles.teaserText: A plane that crashed after the pilot made a bet with the first officer that he could land it blind. Unfortunately for 70 people on board, he couldn't.

articles.title: Ampelmännchen
articles.teaserText: The East German "traffic-light little-man" (Ampelmännchen).

articles.title: Amtrak paint schemes
articles.teaserText: Various colors of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak).

articles.title: AVE Mizar
articles.teaserText: This nightmare lovechild of a Cessna Skymaster and a Ford Pinto eventually killed its inventor.

articles.title: Bayside Canadian Railway
articles.teaserText: A 220 foot (70 meter) long railway created solely to exploit a loophole in the Jones Act. U.S. Customs and Border Protection found out and promptly issued a $350 million fine.

articles.title: Billups Neon Crossing Signal
articles.teaserText: A local inventor's extreme solution to railway crossing safety.

articles.title: Boaty McBoatface
articles.teaserText: What happens when you allow the British public to name a ship in an online poll?

articles.title: British Rail flying saucer
articles.teaserText: Is it a bird? Is it a plane? No, it's the 10:13 to Venus.
