articles.title: Cycloped
articles.teaserText: The entrant into the Rainhill Trial that placed Horse Power against Steam Power.

articles.title: Dagen H
articles.teaserText: September 3, 1967: The day that Sweden changed its traffic directionality.

articles.title: Deli Mike
articles.teaserText: An aircraft that does what she wants.

articles.title: Dymaxion car
articles.teaserText: A 1933 concept car with 3 wheels. It was 20 feet (6.1 m) long, carried up to 11 passengers, could go at speeds of up to 120 miles per hour (190 km/h), and had a steering wheel that turned the car in the opposite direction. One of Buckminster Fuller's Dymaxion concepts.

articles.title: Experiment
articles.teaserText: A boat with eight horse-powers. Literally.

articles.title: Get Out and Push Railroad
articles.teaserText: Just what it sounds like.

articles.title: Ferry Lina
articles.teaserText: The world's shortest regular ferry located in Sweden that takes 25-30 seconds (depends of how strong you are).

articles.title: Gimli Glider
articles.teaserText: A confusion over units leads to a Boeing 767 plane running out of fuel mid-flight and becoming a glider.

articles.title: Human mail
articles.teaserText: Why buy an expensive ticket when you can go by mail?

articles.title: Iron Dobbin
articles.teaserText: A mechanical horse made in 1933 for the Italian Fascist Youth Movement.

articles.title: Jesus nut
articles.teaserText: Not your local Bible-thumping preacher but the bolt on the top of a helicopter that connects it to the rotor blades.

articles.title: Loose wheel nut indicator
articles.teaserText: Yes, those little red tags you see on truck wheels really do have a purpose.

articles.title: M-497 Black Beetle
articles.teaserText: The New York Central Railroad decided to see what would happen when they strapped two jet engines on a railcar; this was the result. It currently holds the record for fastest train in the Americas at 183.68 mph (295.6 km/h).

articles.title: Mile High Club
articles.teaserText: Soaring members.

articles.title: Mehran Karimi Nasseri
articles.teaserText: An Iranian refugee who lived in Charles de Gaulle Airport from 1988 until 2006.

articles.title: Men's parking space
articles.teaserText: An antonym to women's parking space. The only known instances are two spaces in a garage in Germany.

articles.title: Miss Belvedere
articles.teaserText: A car buried in a time capsule in 1957 and unearthed in 2007, only to discover that it had suffered 50 years of water damage underground and wouldn't start.

articles.title: Paternoster lift
articles.teaserText: Strange European elevators without doors that travel in a loop. Considered by many to be very dangerous.

articles.title: Parliamentary train
articles.teaserText: In the United Kingdom, it is cheaper to keep an unwanted railway station open than to close it. This is why there are some railway stations not officially closed with no services in the United Kingdom.

articles.title: Passenger train toilets
articles.teaserText: Why passengers must be discouraged from flushing or using toilets while the train is at a station.

articles.title: Peel P50
articles.teaserText: The world's smallest production car.

articles.title: Plastic bicycle
articles.teaserText: It seems that making bikes out of plastic is not a recipe for success.

articles.title: PZL M-15 Belphegor
articles.teaserText: A Soviet attempt at a turbofan-powered crop duster. It is the slowest jet aircraft to enter production as well as the only jet biplane or jet crop duster to exist.

articles.title: Rail transport in Vatican City
articles.teaserText: It consists of a 680-metre (2,230 ft) branch line and was constructed as a direct result of the Vatican's recognition as a country.

articles.title: Reliant Regal
articles.teaserText: A three-wheeled car formerly manufactured in England that could be driven with a motorcycle license.

articles.title: Rocket mail
articles.teaserText: The delivery of mail by rocket or missile, attempted by various organisations in many different countries, with varying levels of success.

articles.title: RP FLIP
articles.teaserText: A manned ship designed to be capsized at a 90° angle for weeks on end.

articles.title: Schienenzeppelin
articles.teaserText: An unholy combination of a Zeppelin and a locomotive.

articles.title: School bus yellow
articles.teaserText: A color especially formulated for use on school buses in the United States.

articles.title: Screw-propelled vehicle
articles.teaserText: Get there by screwing.

articles.title: Shipping container architecture
articles.teaserText: The concept and art of using intermodal containers to build stuff.

articles.title: Society for the Prevention of Calling Sleeping Car Porters George
articles.teaserText: An association formed to oppose the custom of addressing railway sleeping car porters as "George" regardless of their actual name.

articles.title: South Pointing Chariot
articles.teaserText: An ancient Chinese mechanical compass which took a millennium to reproduce.

articles.title: Tall bike
articles.teaserText: A bike which consists of two conventional bicycle frames connected one atop the other.

articles.title: Train surfing
articles.teaserText: As respectable and practical as drying one's hair in most parts of the world.

articles.title: Unused highway
articles.teaserText: Lost highways, unloved and unused.

articles.title: Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571
articles.teaserText: Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571, later known as the Andes Flight Disaster and the Miracle of the Andes, was a chartered flight that originated in Montevideo, Uruguay, where the passengers were forced to resort to cannibalism after it crashed.

articles.title: USGlobal Airways
articles.teaserText: An active airline founded in 1989 that has never operated a single commercial flight.

articles.title: Vomit Comet
articles.teaserText: Lack of gravity is not good for the stomach.

articles.title: Vortech Meg-2XH Strap-On
articles.teaserText: A discontinued strap-on helicopter designed for amateur construction. Somehow no lawsuits are mentioned in the article.

articles.title: Wallsend Metro station
articles.teaserText: All railroads lead to Rome. With "no smoking" signs, although tobacco was unknown to ancient Romans...

articles.title: Westray to Papa Westray flight
articles.teaserText: The world's shortest passenger flight, lasting as little as 53 seconds. Just don't expect an in-flight meal.

articles.title: The wrong type of snow
articles.teaserText: Possibly the most feeble excuse for why British trains are so awful.

articles.title: .nu
articles.teaserText: Niue's top-level domain, which is regulated by Sweden and almost exclusively used by European countries.

articles.title: .tv
articles.teaserText: Sales of websites under this top-level domain name make up 10% of Tuvalu's GDP.

articles.title: Any key
articles.teaserText: Press any key to continue.

articles.title: Blinkenlights
articles.teaserText: DAS KOMPUTERMASCHINE IST NICHT FÜR DER GEFINGERPOKEN UND MITTENGRABEN!

articles.title: The Book of Mozilla
articles.teaserText: A well-known computer Easter egg found in the Netscape and Mozilla series of browsers.

articles.title: Brainfuck
articles.teaserText: An intentionally difficult to use programming language containing only eight commands.

articles.title: Brian's Brain
articles.teaserText: He's so smart, he has his own cellular automaton.

articles.title: Bush hid the facts
articles.teaserText: Revelations of a vast right-wing conspiracy, or just a glitch?

articles.title: Chudnovsky brothers
articles.teaserText: A pair of mathematicians who built a supercomputer out of spare parts.

articles.title: Conway's Game of Life
articles.teaserText: A simple game with only three rules that people have made beautifully complex machines with, including a computer that runs Conway's Game of Life.

articles.title: Electric unicycle
articles.teaserText: The ongoing academic effort to teach robots to ride unicycles.

articles.title: Elvis operator
articles.teaserText: An operator in programming languages with an unusual name.

articles.title: Emojli
articles.teaserText: A defunct emoji-only social network. Started as a parody of Yo (see below).

articles.title: Esoteric programming language

articles.title: Evil bit
articles.teaserText: Indicates if a packet has been sent with malicious intent, so that it can be ignored.

articles.title: Guru Meditation error
articles.teaserText: If you thought the blue screen of death was bad, this computer error would hamper your quest to reach Nirvana.

articles.title: I Am Rich
articles.teaserText: You must be if you could afford this US$999.99 iPhone application that only displayed a red gem and a (misspelled) mantra.

articles.title: IP over Avian Carriers
articles.teaserText: An Internet protocol for sending data packets using homing pigeons.

articles.title: iSmell
articles.teaserText: A computer peripheral designed to emit smells for websites and emails, later named one of the "Worst Tech Products" by PC Magazine.

articles.title: Leet
articles.teaserText: T3h 1@ngu/\&e 0f H@xx0rz.

articles.title: Lenna
articles.teaserText: How an image of a nude Playboy model became the industry-standard digital image compression test subject.

articles.title: lp0 on fire
articles.teaserText: Want to panic a Unix user? Display an error that their printer is on fire.

articles.title: Macquarium
articles.teaserText: Vintage Macintosh computers-turned-fishtanks.

articles.title: MONIAC

articles.title: On the Cruelty of Really Teaching Computer Science
articles.teaserText: A 1990 academic paper which argues that computer programming should be understood as a branch of mathematics, and that the formal provability of a program is a major criterion for correctness.

articles.title: Pentium F00F bug
articles.teaserText: An Intel Pentium bug with an unusual name.

articles.title: Reality distortion field
articles.teaserText: Surely an obscure quantum-physics phenomenon? Nope!

articles.title: Rubber duck debugging
articles.teaserText: Code debugging by explaining your code to a rubber duck. Quack!

articles.title: Rubber-hose cryptanalysis
articles.teaserText: Cryptography by other means.

articles.title: Scunthorpe problem
articles.teaserText: Spam filtering based on text strings can cause problems. Just ask the residents of S****horpe.

articles.title: Send Me To Heaven
articles.teaserText: A mobile game won by throwing your phone as close to heaven as you can without it getting there.

articles.title: Tay (bot)

articles.teaserText: A spiritualist who claimed that dead composers dictated new musical works to her.

articles.title: Brian Wilson is a genius
articles.teaserText: A music journalist's meme from the 1960s that arguably destroyed the career of the Beach Boys' main songwriter and producer. (Within three years, Wilson was working as a grocery store cashier.)

articles.title: Clapton is God
articles.teaserText: Graffiti that's famous for a photo of a dog urinating on it.

articles.title: Clear Channel memorandum
articles.teaserText: America banning Learn to Fly by Foo Fighters from radio airplay after 9/11 is an odd choice. Though What a Wonderful World by Louis Armstrong brings to mind more questions.

articles.title: Curse of the ninth
articles.teaserText: The superstition that any composer of symphonies, from Beethoven onwards, will die soon after writing their own Ninth Symphony.

articles.title: Dark Side of the Rainbow
articles.teaserText: What happens when you mix Pink Floyd and The Wizard of Oz?

articles.title: Earworm
articles.teaserText: It's got a hook in you.

articles.title: Elvis impersonator
articles.teaserText: People pretend to be Elvis Presley and only him.

articles.title: Elvis sightings
articles.teaserText: There are many who still believe.

articles.title: Fogerty v. Fantasy, Inc.
articles.teaserText: That time John Fogerty was sued for sounding like himself.

articles.title: Fyre Festival
articles.teaserText: The organizers spent so much money promoting the event that they ran out of money to spend on the actual event. They were later faced with eight lawsuits.

articles.title: Industrial musical
articles.teaserText: Not a subgenre of industrial music, but a musical production performed for the employees of a business, intended to create a feeling of being part of a team, or to educate and motivate the management and salespeople to improve sales and profit.

articles.title: List of classical music concerts with an unruly audience response
articles.teaserText: Concerts which didn't work out quite as well as hoped.

articles.title: List of nontraditional bagpipe usage
articles.teaserText: Some unorthodox uses for the good ol' Scottish lung.

articles.title: Literal music video
articles.teaserText: What happens when you replace the lyrics in a music video with lyrics that describe what's actually happening in the music video? Hilarity ensues.

articles.title: Loudness war
articles.teaserText: Why recorded music is getting "louder" over time.

articles.title: Manualism
articles.teaserText: The little-known art of playing music by squeezing air through the hands.

articles.title: Marilyn Manson–Columbine High School massacre controversy
articles.teaserText: News media falsely accused Marilyn Manson and his band of the same name for influencing two mass shooters who actually hated his music.

articles.title: More Cowbell
articles.teaserText: I got a fever, and the only prescription... is more cowbell!

articles.title: More popular than Jesus
articles.teaserText: A remark that later proved deadly for John Lennon.

articles.title: Mozart and scatology
articles.teaserText: Mozart was fond of toilet humour, his letters to friends and family often contained scatological passages. He even wrote music dedicated to scatology, which was shared among a closed group of most likely inebriated friends, the most infamous of which is Leck mich im Arsch (literally "Lick me in the arse").

articles.title: Musikalisches Würfelspiel
articles.teaserText: A system written by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, in which the musical piece is decided randomly by playing dice.

articles.title: My Way killings
articles.teaserText: You can get killed for singing Frank Sinatra's signature tune in the Philippines.

articles.title: P-Funk mythology
articles.teaserText: The whimsical universe surrounding the P Funk all stars.

articles.title: Paul is dead
articles.teaserText: Was Paul McCartney replaced by a lookalike in the 1960s?

articles.title: Pink Floyd pigs
articles.teaserText: The band's recurring props and references.

articles.title: PopMart Tour
articles.teaserText: Take an unfinished studio album, hold a press conference at Kmart, and put on a show in countries around the world, complete with a spinning mirrorball lemon, a giant martini olive, a large golden arch, and the largest video screen ever toured. That would be U2's 1997–98 tour in a nutshell.

articles.title: Publius Enigma
articles.teaserText: A mystery wrapped in an enigma related to Pink Floyd, which has remained unsolved since it appeared on Usenet in 1994.

articles.title: Operation Nifty Package
articles.teaserText: How do you get a dictator out of an embassy? With Music, of course!

articles.title: Rockism and poptimism
articles.teaserText: What happens when pop music fans take themselves way too seriously? Actually, nothing fun.

articles.title: Up to eleven
articles.teaserText: This article is one louder.

articles.title: Whamageddon
articles.teaserText: A festive music challenge where you have to avoid listening to a certain Christmas song throughout the Christmas period. Perfect if you're not a fan of George Michael.

articles.title: Blackbird
articles.teaserText: A playable violin made out of black stone.

articles.title: Cat organ
articles.teaserText: A keyboard instrument in which the keys cause cats to meow.

articles.title: Electroencephalophone
articles.teaserText: A musical instrument controlled by brainwaves.

articles.title: Escopetarra
articles.teaserText: The Colombian gun-guitar.

articles.title: Musical saw
articles.teaserText: The least favourite instrument of Ronnie Wood, the Hollies and the Screaming Trees.

articles.title: Ugly stick
articles.teaserText: An instrument in Newfoundland, an insult everywhere else.

articles.title: Viola jokes
articles.teaserText: You can tell if a viola player is playing out of tune if you can see the bow moving.

articles.title: Chap hop
articles.teaserText: Rap music about being English in the 19th-century.

articles.title: Chillwave
articles.teaserText: The term was invented to make fun of music journalists and bloggers who hype "the next big thing". Ironically, they then wrote about chillwave as "the next big thing".

articles.title: Christian ska
articles.teaserText: Psychedelic worship music.

articles.title: Danger music
articles.teaserText: The name is very much literal, music that tries to harm the listener or performer.

articles.title: Gothabilly
articles.teaserText: What if Buddy Holly was goth?

articles.title: Grunge speak
articles.teaserText: That time a receptionist convinced The New York Times that "wack slacks" was slang for ripped jeans and "lamestain" meant an uncool person.

articles.title: Pirate metal
articles.teaserText: Heavy metal music combined with pirate mythology and jargon.

articles.title: Proibidão
articles.teaserText: As part of a crackdown on drug cartels in Rio de Janeiro, this uniquely Brazilian form of gangsta rap cannot legally be performed or broadcast on the radio.

articles.title: AKB48 Group
articles.teaserText: Girl group or franchise? Same with her "official" rival group and "spin-off" group as well!

articles.title: Bull of Heaven
articles.teaserText: A group that is known for their extremely long albums. Most known for 210: Like a Wall in Which An Insect Lives and Gnaws; at a runtime of 5.7 years; their longest album is 310: ΩΣPx0(2^18×5^18)p*k*k*k at 3.343 quindecillion years long.

articles.title: GG Allin
articles.teaserText: An anarchist punk-rocker, who would attack people attending his concerts, consisting of hoarse, disheveled vocals. He would also take an excessive amount of drugs, strip naked, and defecate on stage.

articles.title: CD Rev
articles.teaserText: Because nothing says gangsta like being funded by a corrupt communist government.

articles.title: Matt Farley
articles.teaserText: A songwriter who has released thousands of songs under at least seventy pseudonyms such as "Papa Razzi and the Photogs", "The Hungry Food Band", and "The Odd Man Who Sings About Poop, Puke and Pee"

articles.title: Joyce Hatto
articles.teaserText: A pianist who had many doctored recordings falsely attributed to her long after she stopped performing in public.

articles.title: Bobby Jameson
articles.teaserText: A hippie singer-songwriter outcast who never received financial compensation for his songs and records. Thought to be dead after the 1960s, but then resurfaced with a blog in 2007 aiming to set the record straight about his life story.

articles.title: Jandek
articles.teaserText: A prolific and pseudonymous singer/songwriter active since 1978 who only grants the occasional interview and has never provided any biographical information.

articles.title: Florence Foster Jenkins
articles.teaserText: An American soprano famous for her singing ability or lack thereof.

articles.title: Hanatarash
articles.teaserText: The Japanese noise band that drove a bulldozer into their concert venue.

articles.title: Hatari
articles.teaserText: A band that entered the 2019 Söngvakeppnin (Iceland's Eurovision Song Contest selection competition) as a joke, only to win first place. The band then won third place in Eurovision's semi-finals, advancing to the Grand Final and winning 10th place there.

articles.title: Hatebeak
articles.teaserText: The thing that should not beak.

articles.title: Okilly Dokilly
articles.teaserText: A band that performs metalcore songs about the character Ned Flanders from The Simpsons, while dressed as the character as well.

articles.title: Kevin MacLeod
articles.teaserText: Perhaps the most heard musician on the whole internet.

articles.title: Merzbow
articles.teaserText: A Japanese experimental music group whose most popular album has been affectionately described as "What a bug hears when it's being flushed down the toilet" and "Directly looking at the sun with your ears".

articles.title: Moondog
articles.teaserText: A blind composer, theoretician, poet, and inventor of musical instruments who dressed like a viking and lived as a street musician in New York between the 1940s and 1970s.

articles.title: MP4
articles.teaserText: Rock music and Members of Parliament do mix.

articles.title: One Pound Fish Man
articles.teaserText: A man who works at a market who saw his sales patter go viral and challenge The X Factor for the Christmas number one single in 2012.

articles.title: Eilert Pilarm
articles.teaserText: The Elvis impersonator who looks and sounds nothing like Elvis, according to Alfo Media.

articles.title: R. Stevie Moore
articles.teaserText: A one-man band who has self-released over 400 albums through his home-based mailing service since 1982. Later noted as a pioneer of DIY music and indie rock.

articles.title: The Shaggs
articles.teaserText: None of this band's members really wanted to form a band, nor did they really have any musical talent, but hey, a fortune teller predicted success, so off they went...

articles.title: Thai Elephant Orchestra
articles.teaserText: An orchestra of elephants playing specially-designed instruments.

articles.title: Tout-à-Coup Jazz
articles.teaserText: An African jazz band from the 1970s whose membership included two future Burkinabé leaders, Thomas Sankara and Blaise Compaoré, with the latter overthrowing the other in a 1987 coup. Unbelievably, the band's name was purely coincidental.

articles.title: The Vegetable Orchestra
articles.teaserText: An Austrian orchestra whose musical instruments are made solely from vegetables.

articles.title: Viper
articles.teaserText: Has released over 1,927 albums, though a majority contain recycled material. Titles of his work include You'll Cowards Don't Even Smoke Crack and Kill Urself My Man.

articles.title: The Wealdstone Raider
articles.teaserText: A supporter of English non-league football team Wealdstone whose retorts towards rival supporters went viral and saw him challenging for the Christmas number one spot in 2014.

articles.title: Wesley Willis
articles.teaserText: A musician and visual artist who recorded songs about topics such as his home town of Chicago, his schizophrenia, violent confrontations with cartoon superheroes, and bestiality, was fond of headbutting fans, and often ended his songs with "Rock over London, rock on, Chicago" followed by a product slogan.

articles.title: Gary Wilson
articles.teaserText: An experimental musician who sings about stalking girls and plays with duct tape, fake blood, powder, and mannequins when on stage.

articles.title: Wild Man Fischer
articles.teaserText: A schizophrenic Los Angeles street entertainer whose big break was recording an album with Frank Zappa. Their collaborations ended when Fischer, in a violent rage, threw a bottle that nearly hit Zappa's daughter Moon.

articles.title: The Zimmers
articles.teaserText: A rock band made up of elderly musicians. As of 2017, the oldest member had lived to 101.

articles.title: The Zombeatles
articles.teaserText: Paul is undead.

articles.title: The Anacreontic Song
articles.teaserText: An 18th-century drinking song whose melody was later adopted for "The Star-Spangled Banner".

articles.title: As Slow as Possible
articles.teaserText: A piece of music by John Cage to be performed until 2640.

articles.title: Carnival of Light
articles.teaserText: The Holy Grail for Beatles fans: an 11-minute recording of the Fab Four aimlessly bashing their instruments and shouting gibberish.

articles.title: Grosse Fuge
articles.teaserText: A composition written by Ludwig van Beethoven which was universally put down at the time as being "incomprehensible", now accepted as one of his greatest works.

articles.title: Helikopter-Streichquartett
articles.teaserText: A string quartet composition by Karlheinz Stockhausen that must be played in four circling helicopters, the sound remixed, chopper sounds and all, for an audience on the ground.

articles.title: Leck mich im Arsch
articles.teaserText: A canon, whose title translates as "Lick Me in the Arse", by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

articles.title: List of silent musical compositions
articles.teaserText: Not to be confused with "The Sound of Silence", these tunes don't have really much to hear.

articles.title: List of music considered the worst
articles.teaserText: We built this city on not being very good.

articles.title: Rage Over a Lost Penny
articles.teaserText: An audience favorite from Beethoven's oeuvre. It's gleefully angry, but the maestro left it unfinished.

articles.title: Boris Johnson Is a Fucking Cunt
articles.teaserText: A foul-mouthed comedy punk song about the British Prime Minister that attempted to be the UK Christmas number one in 2020. Despite getting no air time, it got to No. 5. The following year, it spawned a sequel, which also got to No. 5 in the Christmas chart. From the same band that brought you "Prince Andrew Is a Sweaty Nonce".

articles.title: Camouflage
articles.teaserText: A vinyl single from 1983 that contained a computer programme for the song's own music video for the ZX81. Created by a man who later found fame wearing a papier-mâché head.

articles.title: Eat Your Salad
articles.teaserText: The Latvian entry of the Eurovision Song Contest 2022. The lyrics speak of "eating veggies and p*ssy", along with numerous other sexual innuendos. Somehow, the song still has a serious message.

articles.title: Euro-Vision
articles.teaserText: The Belgian entry of the Eurovision Song Contest 1980 whose lyrics spoke precisely of the event in which they took part.

articles.title: Five Per Cent for Nothing
articles.teaserText: A very short instrumental by a band noted for very long songs that was retitled as a parting shot at their former manager, who sued them afterwards.

articles.title: Flappie
articles.teaserText: A Dutch Christmas song about cannibalism.

articles.title: Give That Wolf a Banana
articles.teaserText: A song that combines Little Red Riding Hood and two crazy 4.5 billion year old yellow wolves called Keith and Jim. The meaning of the song is debated, but one common theory is of all things, vaccines. It's also a Eurovision song, to boot.

articles.title: Hitler Has Only Got One Ball
articles.teaserText: Was der Führer only half a man?

articles.title: Jeg har set en rigtig negermand
articles.teaserText: A Danish #1 single from 1970, extolling the virtues of racial equality while calling a "negro man" "black as a bucket of tar".

articles.title: Jiggle Jiggle
articles.teaserText: That time when an autotuned interview with Louis Theroux became so popular they convinced him to do a song.

articles.title: Lift Yourself
articles.teaserText: What do you get when one of the world's most acclaimed rappers, who is also notoriously neurodivergent, decides a beat is too good for a rival rapper to own? Hint: Poopy-di scoop. Scoop-diddy-whoop. Whoop-di-scoop-di-poop.

articles.title: The Most Mysterious Song on the Internet
articles.teaserText: The name says it all. (Well, almost.)

articles.title: The Most Unwanted Song
articles.teaserText: Featuring operatic rapping, a children's choir urging listeners to go to Wal-Mart, bagpipes, cowboy music, and political slogans shouted through a bullhorn.

articles.title: Never Learn Not to Love
articles.teaserText: The Beach Boys' collaboration with Charles Manson. (Yes, that Charles Manson.)

articles.title: Nyah nyah nyah nyah nyah nyah
articles.teaserText: If you can see someone's underwear, here's the tune to tell them by.

articles.title: Prisencolinensinainciusol
articles.teaserText: The song where the lyrics are deliberately unintelligible gibberish intended to sound to its Italian audience as if it is sung in English spoken with an American accent.

articles.title: Ram Ranch
articles.teaserText: A spoken-word heavy metal song about a gay cowboy orgy that became an internet meme and a counter-protest song against the Canadian convoy protest.

articles.title: Ready 'n' Steady
articles.teaserText: A song mentioned in a top songs list of a notable magazine, that was long-believed by some to be non-existent because collectors were unable to find a recording or further information on it until 33 years after it was written.

articles.title: Tetris
articles.teaserText: A Eurodance version of the Tetris theme co-produced by Andrew Lloyd Webber.

articles.title: There's No One as Irish as Barack O'Bama
articles.teaserText: A 2008 song celebrating the Irish heritage of then-candidate for President of the United States Barack Obama.

articles.title: Timothy
articles.teaserText: A top 40 hit in 1970, written by Rupert Holmes of "The Piña Colada Song" fame, that gained success despite (or due to) the fact it was about cannibalism during a mining disaster.

articles.title: United Breaks Guitars
articles.teaserText: A protest song against United Airlines which caused their stock price to fall by 10% and cost shareholders $180 million.

articles.title: We Didn't Start the Fire
articles.teaserText: A song covering the major events of 40 years. Check Events mentioned for explanations of each.

articles.title: You Suffer
articles.teaserText: At a full 1.316 seconds in length, the shortest song with a physical single release of all time.

articles.title: You're Pitiful
articles.teaserText: The true story of how a Weird Al Yankovic parody caused the article for Atlantic Records to be regularly vandalized.

articles.title: A Rubber Band Christmas
articles.teaserText: An album of Christmas music created using office supplies.

articles.title: All Lights Fucked on the Hairy Amp Drooling
articles.teaserText: An early album by Godspeed You! Black Emperor, which had a tiny release and was impossibly rare until a 2022 release.

articles.title: The Boy Bands Have Won
articles.teaserText: Actually, this album's full title is "The Boy Bands Have Won" followed by a further 151 words. As of August 2009, it holds the record for the longest album title.

articles.title: Cigarettes and Valentines
articles.teaserText: An entire record by Green Day whose master tracks were stolen. This led to the creation of American Idiot.

articles.title: Dark Night of the Soul
articles.teaserText: Due to a legal dispute, this album was released with a blank CD-R.

articles.title: Eat Shit You Fucking Redneck
articles.teaserText: Pigface doesn't like rednecks so much.

articles.title: Elvis' Greatest Shit
articles.teaserText: Not the one he was trying to pass the night he allegedly died.

articles.title: Everywhere at the End of Time
articles.teaserText: A 61⁄2 hour concept album series portraying the stages of mental deterioration caused by Alzheimer's disease. Sounds obscure? It became popular in the most unexpected of places.

articles.title: Everyday Chemistry
articles.teaserText: A supposed album by the Beatles, from an alternate dimension where they never broke up.

articles.title: In Search of The
articles.teaserText: A box set isn't particularly unusual. A box set of 13 full albums that have never been released before, handmade by the artist, is pretty unusual.

articles.title: The Lillywhite Sessions
articles.teaserText: Never officially released, and yet fans and critics can argue that it's the best "album" by the Dave Matthews Band.

articles.title: Metal Machine Music
articles.teaserText: A 1975 album by Lou Reed that consists of 64 minutes of audio feedback, widely believed to have either been an elaborate joke, or an attempt by Reed to escape from a record label contract.

articles.title: The Monty Python Matching Tie and Handkerchief
articles.teaserText: A three-sided LP.

articles.title: Musique pour Supermarché
articles.teaserText: This album by Jean-Michel Jarre had only a single copy produced, which was then auctioned off like a painting. The master tapes were subsequently destroyed, making the copy unique.

articles.title: Once Upon a Time in Shaolin
articles.teaserText: A Wu-Tang Clan album that only had one copy produced, being bought by Martin Shkreli for two million dollars, making it the most expensive work of music ever sold.

articles.title: Sleep
articles.teaserText: An 81⁄2 hour concept album about sleep. Also available in a one-hour version if you're in a hurry.

articles.title: Sleepify
articles.teaserText: Silence is golden, especially when you're trying to fund a world tour.

articles.title: Smile
articles.teaserText: An unfinished Beach Boys album that is one of the most written-about and speculated-upon works in popular music history.

articles.title: Sweet Insanity
articles.teaserText: A rejected Brian Wilson album that was written and recorded with his ex-psychologist. Includes a rap song that opens with the line, "My name is Brian and I'm the man, I write hit songs with the wave of my hand!" Wilson's fans threatened to murder a critic for publishing a positive review.

articles.title: Trout Mask Replica'
articles.teaserText: A chaotic 1969 album by Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band containing bizarre and disjointed musical compositions.

articles.title: 100 Years
articles.teaserText: A movie that your grandchildren and great-grandchildren might be able to enjoy!

articles.title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn
articles.teaserText: A movie about a director who makes a bad movie, but can't remove his name from the credits because his real name is Alan Smithee. In reality, the movie about the movie was so bad that director Arthur Hiller was credited as Alan Smithee to disguise himself from the production.

articles.title: Big Dumb Object
articles.teaserText: A mysterious object (usually of extraterrestrial origin) in a film that is there simply to cause a sense of wonder.

articles.title: Black and white hat symbolism in film
articles.teaserText: The hat, sir, whatever could it mean?

articles.title: The Cure for Insomnia
articles.teaserText: A movie that runs for 85 hours. Not the longest movie ever screened though (see below).

articles.title: The Day the Clown Cried
articles.teaserText: A notorious unreleased film about the Holocaust by Jerry Lewis – hey, it's a comedy!

articles.title: Dump months
articles.teaserText: The opposite of the summer movie season.

articles.title: Empire
articles.teaserText: A film by Andy Warhol consisting entirely of eight hours of still footage of the Empire State Building.

articles.title: Empires of the Deep
articles.teaserText: A $140 million unreleased US-Chinese aqua-fantasy film that sunk to the depths of the sea...

articles.title: First on the Moon
articles.teaserText: Proof that the Soviets got there, thirty years before Armstrong and Aldrin didn't.

articles.title: I Killed My Lesbian Wife, Hung Her on a Meat Hook, and Now I Have a Three-Picture Deal at Disney
articles.teaserText: "I knew I wanted to be a director, and I did a couple of short films, and this is the only one that haunts me." —Ben Affleck, Academy Award winner

articles.title: Lee Kin-yan
articles.teaserText: A Hong Kong actor repeatedly cast in Stephen Chow films as a nose-picking, bearded transvestite.

articles.title: List of films featuring giant monsters
articles.teaserText: You are never safe in Tokyo.

articles.title: List of films that most frequently use the word fuck
articles.teaserText: Golly!

articles.title: Logistics
articles.teaserText: The world's longest movie ever made, it follows the entire five-week process of making and selling a pedometer in reverse chronological order.

articles.title: The Longest Most Meaningless Movie in the World
articles.teaserText: A movie that runs for 48 hours. Despite its title, it isn't the world's longest movie, but the jury's still out on whether it's the most meaningless....

articles.title: Maidstone
articles.teaserText: A film where a director runs for president while being targeted for assassination attempts, which is notable for a fight scene that made it into the final cut, where actor Rip Torn hits director Norman Mailer on the head with a hammer.

articles.title: Manic Pixie Dream Girl
articles.teaserText: A female stock character in (usually) movies who is extremely eccentric and girlish, and serves mainly to motivate and/or provide character development for the male protagonist.

articles.title: Manos: The Hands of Fate
articles.teaserText: A low-budget film created by a fertilizer salesman from Texas, which is largely considered to be the worst film of all time.

articles.title: Mockbuster
articles.teaserText: Not the movie you want, but the bargain-bin equivalent.

articles.title: Modern Times Forever (Stora Enso Building, Helsinki)
articles.teaserText: The second longest film ever shot: ten whole days of one decaying building Life After People-style and first screened in front of itself. The directors have a point.

articles.title: Oscar bait
articles.teaserText: There are certain rules one follows when making an Oscar film. Including mental illness, the Holocaust and Meryl Streep in your film also helps.

articles.title: On the Art of the Cinema
articles.teaserText: North Korean cinema is best Korean cinema.

articles.title: Paint Drying
articles.teaserText: Created to test the patience of the British Board of Film Classification.

articles.title: Patterson–Gimlin film
articles.teaserText: Bigfoot's most famous appearance.

articles.title: Plan 9 from Outer Space
articles.teaserText: The epitome of so-bad-it's-good cinema, and Bela Lugosi's last film. Starring posthumously, Lugosi died before production began.

articles.title: Pulgasari
articles.teaserText: A Godzilla-esque film, supposedly an allegory for unchecked capitalism, created by Kim Jong-il and a director whom he kidnapped.

articles.title: Rapsittie Street Kids: Believe in Santa
articles.teaserText: An all-star cast appear in this badly written, badly animated picture. The producer apparently gave the animators $500,000 and didn't check their work until he saw it on television.

articles.title: Raza
articles.teaserText: A drama about a family's roles in the Spanish Civil War that was written and supposingly ghost-directed by Francisco Franco himself. Takes "history is written by the victors" to a new level.

articles.title: Roar
articles.teaserText: What do you think happens when a family of African wildlife activists gathers together to make an environmentalist movie with over 150 untrained big cats? Seventy members of the cast and crew getting injured, with the worst victim needing 220 stitches; high turnover, with 20 members of the crew leaving en masse; and a combination of financial problems, a broken dam, and destroyed fences resulting in millions in debt.

articles.title: The Room
articles.teaserText: Perhaps the worst film ever created, filled with bad acting, poor dialogue, scenes that go nowhere, crazy behind-the-scenes, and more. And, of course, the man behind it all.

articles.title: Roundhay Garden Scene
articles.teaserText: The first ever moving picture, which lasted for an epic two seconds.

articles.title: Shaken, not stirred
articles.teaserText: Why 007 prefers his martini shaken.

articles.title: Smell-O-Vision
articles.teaserText: A system designed to enhance films with odors. Used once for the 1960 film Scent of Mystery and never again.

articles.title: Stay Puft Marshmallow Man
articles.teaserText: "I tried to think of the most harmless thing. Something I loved from my childhood. Something that could never ever possibly destroy us!"

articles.title: Stinking badges
articles.teaserText: Something nobody needs. Possibly the most frequently quoted and misquoted line from a movie ever.

articles.title: Twin films
articles.teaserText: When two studios make the same idea at the same time.

articles.title: United Passions
articles.teaserText: A $30 million film sponsored by FIFA about how great they are. Came out right after the 2015 FIFA corruption case came to light. One of the lowest grossing sports movies of all time.

articles.title: Who Killed Captain Alex?
articles.teaserText: A 2010 Ugandan action-comedy film produced on a budget of $85.

articles.title: Wilhelm scream
articles.teaserText: A stock sound effect first recorded in 1951 and used in dozens of films (including seven Star Wars films, two Lord of the Rings films and Kill Bill).

articles.title: Zyzzyx Road
articles.teaserText: Budget: $1.2 million. Box office: 30 bucks.

articles.title: Al Murray's Compete for the Meat
articles.teaserText: A British game show where the top prize is a frozen chicken and the second prize is some sausages.

articles.title: Alternative 3
articles.teaserText: An April Fools joke by an ITV science show leads many to believe that scientists were being kidnapped to prepare for the colonization of Mars.

articles.title: Anti-Barney humor
articles.teaserText: An article for all Barney & Friends haters.

articles.title: Australia's Naughtiest Home Videos
articles.teaserText: Forget Turn-On – this never even made it to the end of its only episode.

articles.title: Bernd das Brot
articles.teaserText: The mascot of a German children's television network: a chronically depressed loaf of bread who laments his life and enjoys very boring activities.

articles.title: The Canadian Conspiracy
articles.teaserText: A mockumentary released in 1985 that asserts that Canada is subverting the United States by taking over its media.

articles.title: Conspiracy 58
articles.teaserText: A mockumentary that claimed that the 1958 World Cup was never actually held. Despite being revealed as a hoax at the end, people still believed it.

articles.title: Dennō Senshi Porygon
articles.teaserText: An episode of the "harmless" Pokémon cartoon that caused seizures in almost 700 children.

articles.title: Don't Scare the Hare
articles.teaserText: A British television game show involving a large robotic hare and an underground forest. It was not popular and lasted only one season.

articles.title: Flanderization

People have also claimed he is an important theosophical figure who many have claimed to have met years after his supposed death in 1784.

articles.title: Cynocephaly
articles.teaserText: A half-werewolf? Who knows?

articles.title: Global Orgasm

articles.title: Adrian Carton de Wiart
articles.teaserText: Fought in two World Wars, shot repeatedly, survived two plane crashes, escaped a POW camp, married a countess, and amputated his own fingers when his doctor refused. Also looked like a pirate.

articles.title: Antonov A-40
articles.teaserText: A failed Soviet plan to build an airplane capable of launching tanks in the skies.

articles.title: Vasily Arkhipov
articles.teaserText: Potentially averted a nuclear war.

articles.title: Bolivian Navy
articles.teaserText: Not having access to the sea won't stop Bolivia from having a 5,000 man navy.

articles.title: Boot Monument
articles.teaserText: In celebration of Benedict Arnold's foot.

articles.title: List of camoufleurs
articles.teaserText: Pioneering artists in the field of military camouflage.

articles.title: Jack Churchill
articles.teaserText: Longbows and broadswords weren't used in World War II. Or were they?

articles.title: CONOP 8888
articles.teaserText: The Pentagon's zombie apocalypse plan.

articles.title: Deborah's Hole Camp
articles.teaserText: An Iron Age hillfort situated atop the cliff above Deborah's Hole cave.

articles.title: D-Day Daily Telegraph crossword security alarm
articles.teaserText: Crossword puzzles: A major danger to national security.

articles.title: Devil Eyes
articles.teaserText: A psychological warfare program designed by the CIA to distribute Osama bin Laden action figures throughout South Asia. The faces, when heated, were designed to peel off and reveal a demonic face underneath. They were made by Hasbro, the same company behind the G. I. Joe toys.

articles.title: Dreadnought hoax
articles.teaserText: A practical joke at the expense of the Royal Navy, inspiring the influential Bloomsbury Group.

articles.title: Kamikaze (typhoon)
articles.teaserText: A series of typhoons which were said to have prevented two Mongol fleets from invading Japan, seven years apart.

articles.title: Line-crossing ceremony
articles.teaserText: An initiation rite performed when a ship crosses the equator.

articles.title: List of wartime crossdressers
articles.teaserText: Because war demands proper fashion.

articles.title: Alan Mcilwraith
articles.teaserText: A call center worker who pretended to be a British Army officer, and then pretended to be a magician.

articles.title: Miss Russian Army
articles.teaserText: A beauty contest minus the swimsuit competition but plus the automatic weapons drills.

articles.title: Montauk Project
articles.teaserText: Real military science experiment or urban legend? Maybe the civilians who were in full view of the military base will be able to tell you.

articles.title: Moro Islamic Liberation Front
articles.teaserText: A rebel, some might say terrorist, group in the Southern Philippines who may or may not be aware that their initials are also an acronym for mom I'd like to...

articles.title: Navies of landlocked countries
articles.teaserText: Mongolia once had one of the world's largest navies. Today they have one vessel with a crew of seven sailors, one of them able to swim.

articles.title: Nebraska Admiral
articles.teaserText: The landlocked U.S. state of Nebraska and its "Great Navy".

articles.title: NORAD Tracks Santa
articles.teaserText: A tradition with the American and Canadian military to track Santa Claus for children.

articles.title: Hiroo Onoda
articles.teaserText: A Japanese soldier who hid out in the Philippines during World War II, refusing to surrender until 1974.

articles.title: Stanislav Petrov
articles.teaserText: Another guy who potentially averted nuclear war.

articles.title: Philadelphia Experiment
articles.teaserText: An alleged experiment in 1943 involving electromagnetic technology to render vessels invisible.

articles.title: Portuguese Fireplace
articles.teaserText: A fireplace in the middle of the New Forest.

articles.title: Project A119
articles.teaserText: If you can't land on the Moon, nuke it.

articles.title: Russian warship, go fuck yourself
articles.teaserText: An eternalized catchphrase of the Russo-Ukrainian war.

articles.title: Siachen Glacier
articles.teaserText: The world's highest battlefield, with very predictable terrain.

articles.title: Simo Häyhä
articles.teaserText: Showed some extraordinary Finnish sisu in the Winter War against the Soviets.

articles.title: Skunk (weapon)
articles.teaserText: A nonlethal weapon with an extremely strong odor that may linger on clothes for years.

articles.title: The terrorists have won
articles.teaserText: Or have they?

articles.title: Truelove Eyre
articles.teaserText: A man who supposedly saved William the Conqueror's life during the Battle of Hastings.

articles.title: Zeppelin LZ 66
articles.teaserText: Real-life sky pirates.

articles.title: Zhang Zongchang
articles.teaserText: Eccentric Chinese warlord that, among other things, assigned numbers to his many concubines, as he could not remember all of their names.

articles.title: Dickin Medal
articles.teaserText: Only awarded to animals.

articles.title: Moose cavalry
articles.teaserText: The superposed moose cavalries of Sweden and Russia.

articles.title: Sergeant Stubby
articles.teaserText: The only dog to be promoted to sergeant through combat.

articles.title: United States Camel Corps
articles.teaserText: Full-blooded Arabian mount, imported!

articles.title: Wojtek
articles.teaserText: Arguably the most extraordinary soldier of all time.

articles.title: Anglo-Zanzibar War
articles.teaserText: The world's shortest war. It literally lasted 38 minutes.

articles.title: Attack of the Dead Men
articles.teaserText: Russian combatants looking like zombies win the battle by scaring away the Germans.

articles.title: Battle for Castle Itter
articles.teaserText: American and German soldiers team up against the Nazis in a battle for a medieval castle.

articles.title: Battle of Lake Baikal
articles.teaserText: Czechoslovak Legionnares stole a steamship and won a naval battle against the Red army

articles.title: Bahia Incident
articles.teaserText: Did you know that the American Civil War also took place in Brazil?

articles.title: Battle of Domažlice
articles.teaserText: A Hussite army routs the twice as numerous crusading Holy Roman army with the power of singing.

articles.title: Battle of Fishguard
articles.teaserText: That time when France tried to invade Wales, got drunk and surrendered because they took the British forces too seriously.

articles.title: Battle of Karánsebes
articles.teaserText: How the Austrians fought against themselves over liquor and resulted in 1,200 own casualties.

articles.title: Battle of Kiska
articles.teaserText: In 1943, 7,800 American and Canadian troops invade the island of Kiska which had been occupied by Japan since 1942. Allied forces suffer 122 dead, 300 injured and lose one destroyer due to mines, difficult terrain and friendly fire before realising that the Japanese had secretly abandoned the island two weeks prior.

articles.title: Battle of Tanga
articles.teaserText: A World War I battle where 8,000 British troops were defeated by a German-led force of 1,100 Askaris – aided by swarms of angry bees.

articles.title: Dai Hong Dan incident
articles.teaserText: A North Korean naval vessel was seized by Somali Pirates, then a U.S vessel helped to overpower the pirates.

articles.title: Emu War
articles.teaserText: A military operation undertaken in Western Australia against hordes of emus, or, how large flightless bird triumphs over modernized army.

articles.title: Flagstaff War
articles.teaserText: A war that started between British military forces and the indigenous Polynesian people in New Zealand after a flagstaff was cut down four times.

articles.title: Football War
articles.teaserText: A six-day war fought between El Salvador and Honduras in 1969 that was triggered by a game of football (soccer).

articles.title: Gombe Chimpanzee War
articles.teaserText: A four-year war, fought between two groups of chimpanzees in Tanzania.

articles.title: If Day
articles.teaserText: A simulated Nazi invasion of the Canadian city of Winnipeg, complete with book-burning, arrests of politicians, and newspaper censorship.

articles.title: Iowa Cow War
articles.teaserText: A battle between cow ranchers and the state of Iowa over tuberculosis testing.

articles.title: Operation Mincemeat
articles.teaserText: A misinformation plan to hide the invasion of Sicily using a corpse as a British officer.

articles.title: Operation Paul Bunyan
articles.teaserText: An entire operation by NATO. Over a tree.

articles.title: Operation Pig Bristle
articles.teaserText: A daring air force operation to transport 25 tonnes of pig bristles from Chongqing in China to Hong Kong during the Chinese Civil War. The bristles were shipped to Australia to be made into paint brushes.

articles.title: Operation Tamarisk
articles.teaserText: Claimed to be the most successful intelligence operation in the Cold War; emptying supplies of Soviet Union toilet paper, forcing them to use documents, and retrieving these documents after use.

articles.title: Operation Wikinger
articles.teaserText: Poor communication leads to the German air force scoring a great victory ... against the German navy.

articles.title: Pastry War
articles.teaserText: Looting a pastry shop? This means war!

articles.title: Pig War (1859)
articles.teaserText: A war between the United States and the British Empire that almost erupted over one dead pig.

articles.title: Three Hundred and Thirty Five Years' War
articles.teaserText: A "war" that lasted 335 years without a single shot being fired, between the Netherlands and the tiny Isles of Scilly.

articles.title: Toledo War
articles.teaserText: A war between the State of Ohio and the Michigan Territory that resulted in one injury and over a century of bitterness.

articles.title: Toyota War
articles.teaserText: A war in the last phase of the Chadian–Libyan conflict, named after the Toyota trucks that were used in the battle.

articles.title: War of the Bucket
articles.teaserText: Started when Modenese soldiers stole a bucket from a city well in Bologna.

articles.title: War of Jenkins' Ear
articles.teaserText: A nine-year war, started when Captain Robert Jenkins complained that the Spanish Coastguard had cut off his ear.

articles.title: War of the Stray Dog
articles.teaserText: Greek soldier chases his pooch across the Bulgaria border. Warfare nearly ensues.

articles.title: War of the Insane
articles.teaserText: Hmong revolt against taxing by the French colonial administration in Indochina lasting from 1918 to 1921.

articles.title: War of the League of Cambrai
articles.teaserText: A war that started when France and the Pope attacked Venice. Ended when France and Venice defeated literally everyone else in Western Europe.

articles.title: War Plan Red
articles.teaserText: U.S. war plans from the 1930s to invade Canada in the unlikely event of war with the United Kingdom. Also see the counterpart war plan Defence Scheme No. 1 (the Canadian war plan to invade the United States).

articles.title: Anti-tank dog
articles.teaserText: Failed Soviet weapon of the Second World War.

articles.title: Antonov A-40
articles.teaserText: The "flying tank", an experimental Soviet tank with wings and tailboom, meant to glide into the battlefield, ready for combat. Trials were unsuccessful.

articles.title: Bat bomb
articles.teaserText: A World War II plan to bomb Japan with bats carrying tiny incendiary bombs.

articles.title: Baynes Bat
articles.teaserText: An experimental British glider, designed to convert tanks into gliders which could fly into battle.

articles.title: Bazooka Vespa
articles.teaserText: Placing France at the cutting edge of weapons system design.

articles.title: Bicycle infantry
articles.teaserText: Soldiers have occasionally been trained to use the bicycle for military purposes.

articles.title: Chicken-powered nuclear bomb
articles.teaserText: In a cunningly misnamed project, domestic chickens were set to wage nuclear warfare.

articles.title: Cornfield Bomber
articles.teaserText: An F-106 jet fighter made a perfect gear-up landing in a farmer's field – after the pilot had ejected at 15,000 feet (4,600 m).

articles.title: Dazzle camouflage
articles.teaserText: A colorful way to hide in plain sight.

articles.title: Davy Crockett (nuclear device)
articles.teaserText: A portable nuclear weapon.

articles.title: Double-barreled cannon
articles.teaserText: A failed civil war era attempt to create a weapon of mass destruction. Now a monument in Athens, GA.

articles.title: Explosive rat
articles.teaserText: A World War II weapon designed to cause boiler explosions. Never used, yet still a success.

articles.title: Gay bomb
articles.teaserText: A speculative non-lethal chemical weapon that could be dropped on enemy troops to cause "homosexual behaviour". Not to be confused with the fag bomb.

articles.title: German submarine U-1206
articles.teaserText: A Nazi submarine that was attacked by British forces after it was forced to surface due to a malfunctioning toilet.

articles.title: Grand Panjandrum
articles.teaserText: Britain's World War II Catherine wheel of death.

articles.title: HNLMS Abraham Crijnssen (1936)
articles.teaserText: A Navy ship that attempted to avoid detection by Japanese aircraft and escape back to Australia by having it disguised as a tropical island.

articles.title: Human torpedo
articles.teaserText: Secret naval weapons of World War II.

articles.title: Most-wanted Iraqi playing cards
articles.teaserText: A set of playing cards created by U.S. Army soldiers featuring the most-wanted Iraqis, with Saddam Hussein as the Ace of spades.

articles.title: Project Habakkuk
articles.teaserText: A British plan to construct an aircraft carrier out of ice (pykrete).

articles.title: Project Pigeon
articles.teaserText: Bombs guided by pigeon pecks.

articles.title: Puckle gun
articles.teaserText: A gun with square bullets to be used against non-Christian enemies.

articles.title: Sticky bomb
articles.teaserText: The most unpopular weapon the British soldier has ever been asked to use.

articles.title: Tachanka
articles.teaserText: Twentieth century chariot used in combat.

articles.title: Tsar Tank
articles.teaserText: An Imperial Russian tank designed as a tricycle with nine-metre wheels.

articles.title: United States Navy Marine Mammal Program
articles.teaserText: A U.S. Navy program which studies the military use of Bottlenose Dolphins and California Sea Lions.

articles.title: Who Me
articles.teaserText: A top secret stench weapon designed to be unobtrusively sprayed on German officers by French Resistance members.

articles.title: Zanbatō
articles.teaserText: An enormous Japanese sword that does not exist.

articles.title: Badge Man
articles.teaserText: Unknown figure reportedly visible atop the grassy knoll in the Moorman photo of the Kennedy assassination.

articles.title: Lal Bihari
articles.teaserText: An Indian, who, among other things, ran for elected office despite the notable handicap of being officially dead.

articles.title: Richard Chase
articles.teaserText: The only way to stop the Nazi-controlled UFOs from poisoning your macaroni and cheese is to inject yourself with animal blood and eat human brains.

articles.title: Coffin birth
articles.teaserText: When a pregnant woman dies, the decomposition of her body can result in a gas build-up that causes the fetus inside her to be expelled.

articles.title: Collyer brothers
articles.teaserText: When packratting was taken to a tragic extreme.

articles.title: Death by coconut
articles.teaserText: You can die if a coconut falls on your coconut.

articles.title: Death by GPS
articles.teaserText: Turn-by-turn directions to the afterlife.

articles.title: Death during consensual sex
articles.teaserText: Going out with a bang.

articles.title: Death erection
articles.teaserText: Usually not related to the above.

articles.title: Death from laughter
articles.teaserText: Don't laugh – it's happened.

articles.title: Death by misadventure
articles.teaserText: Death probably due after one saying "Hold my beer, and watch this!"

articles.title: Defenestration
articles.teaserText: The time-honoured tradition of throwing people out of windows.

articles.title: Disappearance of Frederick Valentich
articles.teaserText: An Australian pilot disappeared in the ocean, having seen a strange object above his aircraft. No trace of either his body or the aircraft have been found.

articles.title: Dyatlov Pass Incident
articles.teaserText: A group of Russian hikers attempt to escape an unknown horror on "Death Mountain."

articles.title: Euthanasia Coaster
articles.teaserText: A roller coaster intended to kill its passengers.

articles.title: Execution by elephant
articles.teaserText: An unusual form of capital punishment used throughout history. (See also History of elephants in Europe.)

articles.title: Fan death
articles.teaserText: A persistent urban legend in South Korea, where the media – and even medical professionals – regularly report on people dying because they left a fan running in a closed room.

articles.title: Generalissimo Francisco Franco is still dead
articles.teaserText: An early catch phrase used on Saturday Night Live, based upon the dictator's lengthy death.

articles.title: Ghost bike
articles.teaserText: Bicycle rider in memoriam.

articles.title: Hammersmith nude murders
articles.teaserText: Murders that involved the other unidentified serial killer named Jack, with the title "the Stripper".

articles.title: The Hands of Che Guevara
articles.teaserText: Documentary about the search for the severed hands of the Latin American guerrilla fighter Ernesto Che Guevara, who was captured and executed by Bolivian Special Forces in October 1967.

articles.title: Hell money
articles.teaserText: Apparently, the Chinese afterlife is subject to hyperinflation.

articles.title: Sogen Kato
articles.teaserText: Believed to be the oldest living man in Tokyo... until the discovery of his 30-year-old mummified corpse.

articles.title: Kennedy curse
articles.teaserText: Apparently John F. Kennedy was not the only Kennedy to meet an early demise-far from it.

articles.title: Kick the bucket
articles.teaserText: A heated argument lies behind the origin of this idiom.

articles.title: Lampshades made from human skin
articles.teaserText: They probably wouldn't even be that good at diffusing light.

articles.title: Ricardo López
articles.teaserText: An obsessed fan who attempted to kill Icelandic singer Björk by a letter bomb rigged with sulfuric acid.

articles.title: Henry Lee Lucas
articles.teaserText: Claimed to be the most prolific serial killer in history, confessing to over 600 murders. Later recanted almost all of them.

articles.title: List of expressions related to death
articles.teaserText: "Go home in a box", "go bung", "hop the stick", ...

articles.title: List of people who died on the toilet
articles.teaserText: You could say they died on the throne

articles.title: List of entertainers who died during a performance
articles.teaserText: "And for my last act...I shall die and not come back to life"

articles.title: List of postal killings
articles.teaserText: "Don't let Walter Hobbs deceive you; this life is not all shiny bins and fun", ...

articles.title: List of selfie-related injuries and deaths
articles.teaserText: Extreme cases of people being unaware of their surroundings.

articles.title: Lead Masks Case
articles.teaserText: Two electricians tried to contact aliens with psychedelic drugs and masks made out of lead. They died shortly after.

articles.title: London Necropolis railway station
articles.teaserText: Single tickets only, unless you're a mourner or other visitor.

articles.title: Lord Uxbridge's leg
articles.teaserText: The grisly afterlife of a leg lost during the Battle of Waterloo, formerly owned by Henry Paget, 1st Marquess of Anglesey.

articles.title: Maschalismos
articles.teaserText: The act of mutilating the dead to prevent them from rising again.

articles.title: Michael Malloy
articles.teaserText: Like Rasputin, but homeless, drunk, and Irish.

articles.title: Ken McElroy
articles.teaserText: "Nobody saw nothing" taken to its logical extreme.

articles.title: Micromort
articles.teaserText: A quantitative death risk equivalent to one in a million.

articles.title: Mordred
articles.teaserText: Mordred is back for revenge—watch out!

articles.title: Herbert Mullin
articles.teaserText: Haven't had any earthquakes recently? Thank this man.

articles.title: Oliver Cromwell's head
articles.teaserText: This English political leader's head has an interesting journey after its owner is posthumously executed, more so than the one he cut off himself.

articles.title: Richard Paul Pavlick
articles.teaserText: Plotted to kill then president-elect John F. Kennedy via suicide bombing, but delayed it upon seeing Kennedy with his family.

articles.title: Poe Toaster
articles.teaserText: Not a kitchen appliance, but a mysterious figure who paid an annual tribute to American author Edgar Allan Poe.

articles.title: Post-mortem photography
articles.teaserText: Back in the early days of photography it was common to take pictures of recently deceased loved ones, propped up to look as if they were alive.

articles.title: Refrigerator death
articles.teaserText: A cool way to die.

articles.title: Republican marriage
articles.teaserText: A form of execution in which a naked man and woman are tied together and drowned. (What did you think it was?)

articles.title: Rookwood Cemetery railway line
articles.teaserText: A former railway line that served a cemetery near Sydney.

articles.title: Safety coffin
articles.teaserText: Coffins manufactured just in case their tenant is not actually dead before being buried.

articles.title: Salish Sea human foot discoveries
articles.teaserText: Dismembered feet keep washing up.

articles.title: Frane Selak
articles.teaserText: Dubbed the luckiest/unluckiest man to exist, cheated death seven times and also managed to win the lottery!

articles.title: Sky burial
articles.teaserText: It's not really a form of burial. Also known as jhator which means "giving alms to the birds."

articles.title: Sokushinbutsu
articles.teaserText: A practice of self-mummification among Buddhist monks.

articles.title: Space burial
articles.teaserText: Around 150 people have had their remains interred in space. Or would that be ex-terred?

articles.title: Spontaneous human combustion
articles.teaserText: The sudden burning of a person's body without any apparent source of ignition.

articles.title: Suicide booth
articles.teaserText: A common feature in the world of tomorrow.

articles.title: Tamam Shud case
articles.teaserText: A dead man is found on an Australian beach with no identification and a bizarre fragment of a book in his pocket. To this day, his identity and cause of death are still unknown.

articles.title: Toilet-related injuries and deaths
articles.teaserText: As if constipation wasn't enough.

articles.title: Uttar Pradesh Association of Dead People
articles.teaserText: A group of Indians suffering more from theft than cardiac failure.

articles.title: Joyce Vincent
articles.teaserText: A woman who sat dead in her home with the TV and heater running and Christmas presents on her lap for three years until her corpse was found.

articles.title: Video-Enhanced Grave Marker
articles.teaserText: Graves with video screens and speakers on them.

articles.title: Xin Zhui
articles.teaserText: A remarkably preserved Chinese mummy from 163 B.C. with all features and soft tissue still intact.
